<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10.5
<SEQUENCE>3
<FILENAME>y85716exv10w5.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-10.5: EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT WITH STEPHEN RIGGIO
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>EX-10.5: EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT WITH STEPHEN RIGGIO</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;10.5</B>
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>BARNES &#038; NOBLE, INC.</B>
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>122 Fifth Avenue</B>
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>New York, New York 10011</B>
</FONT>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">As of February&nbsp;18, 2002</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Stephen Riggio<BR>
81 Post Kunhardt Road<BR>
Bernardsville, New Jersey 07924
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Dear Mr.&nbsp;Riggio:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This letter agreement is intended to set forth our mutual understanding
regarding your employment as Chief Executive Officer of Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc.
(the &#147;Company&#148;). Accordingly, we are pleased to agree as follows:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employment; Duties. You agree to be Chief Executive Officer of the
Company for the term of this Agreement. In this capacity you shall perform
such duties and have such responsibilities as are typically associated with the
office of Chief Executive Officer, including such duties and responsibilities
as are prescribed by the Board of Directors of the Company (the &#147;Board&#148;)
consistent with the office of Chief Executive Officer. While you are the
Company&#146;s employee, you agree to devote your full business time and attention
to the performance of your duties and responsibilities hereunder.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Term. (a)&nbsp;Unless terminated earlier in accordance with the provisions
set forth below, the term of this Agreement will be for a period beginning on
the date hereof and ending on the third anniversary of the date hereof. At the
expiration (but not earlier termination) of the term (including any renewal
term), the term of this Agreement shall automatically renew for an additional
period of one year, unless either party has given the other party written
notice of non-renewal at least one year prior to such renewal.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;This Agreement shall terminate upon your death and may be terminated
by the Company by written notice to you following your Disability (as defined
below). This Agreement may also be terminated by the Company for Cause (as
defined below) upon written notice to you. This Agreement may also be
terminated by you for Good Cause (as defined below) upon written notice to the
Company.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;For purposes of this Agreement:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i) &#147;Cause&#148; shall mean (A)&nbsp;your final conviction of a felony
impacting on the performance of your duties or involving a crime of moral
turpitude, or (B)&nbsp;misappropriation or embezzlement in the performance of
your duties as an employee of the Company, or (C)&nbsp;willfully engaging in
conduct materially injurious to the Company and in violation of your
obligations under this Agreement, which violation continues for at least
30&nbsp;days after written notice thereof from the Company to you specifying
such violation in reasonable detail.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(ii) &#147;Disability&#148; shall mean a written determination by a physician
mutually agreeable to the Company and you (or, in the event of your total
physical or mental disability, your legal representative) that you are
physically or mentally unable to perform your duties of Chief Operating
Officer under this Agreement and that such disability can reasonably be
expected to continue for a period of six consecutive months or for
shorter periods aggregating 180&nbsp;days in any 12-month period.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary. The Company will pay you, for all services you perform
hereunder, an annual salary of $650,000, or such higher amount as the
Compensation Committee of the Board (the &#147;Compensation Committee&#148;) may
determine, payable in accordance with the Company&#146;s payroll schedule applicable
to executive officers of the Company.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bonus Compensation. In addition to your above-mentioned salary, we
will pay you, within 90&nbsp;days following the end of each fiscal year of the
Company during the term of your employment, annual bonus compensation in an
amount determined in accordance with the Company&#146;s Supplemental Compensation
Plan. We agree that for the entire term hereof, you shall be entitled to
participate in that plan.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee Benefits. During the term of your employment, you will
participate in and receive any benefits to which you are entitled under
employee benefit plans which the Company provides for all employees, as well as
all benefits which the Company provides, or may at any time in the future
provide, for its executive officers.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Expenses; Car Allowance. During the term of your employment, we
will: (a)&nbsp;pay you a car allowance per month of $1,500, or such higher amount
as may be determined by the Compensation Committee; and (b)&nbsp;reimburse you for
all expenses incurred by you in the performance of your duties and
responsibilities under this Agreement, including, without limitation,
entertainment and travel expenses, in accordance with the policies and
procedures established by the Compensation Committee.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Life and Disability Insurance. In addition to the foregoing, we will
obtain in your name a life insurance policy providing for a death benefit of
$1,000,000 payable to any beneficiary or beneficiaries named by you, and, at
your request, a disability insurance policy providing for monthly payments to
you of at least $12,800 during the period of any disability until the earlier
of your attaining age 65 or death. During the term of your employment, we will
pay all premiums due on such policies.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Severance. In the event of the expiration or termination of the term
of your employment (other than for Cause, your death or Disability, or your
voluntary termination of your employment, whether through resignation,
non-renewal or otherwise), we will pay you a lump sum, within 30&nbsp;days following
such expiration or termination, equal to (a)&nbsp;the sum of (i)&nbsp;your then annual
salary, (ii)&nbsp;your annual bonus for the then most recently completed fiscal year
of the Company, and (iii)&nbsp;the then aggregate annual dollar amount of the
payments made or to be made by the Company for purposes of providing you with
the benefits set forth in paragraphs 3.3 through 3.5 above, multiplied by (b)
the greater of (i)&nbsp;two or (ii)&nbsp;the number of months remaining in the term of
this Agreement divided by 12. You shall be under no duty to mitigate damages
and the amount paid to you under this paragraph 3.6 shall not be diminished in
any way by your earnings or income from any other sources.
</FONT><P align="center"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 3.7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock Options. Contemporaneously with the execution of this
Agreement, the Company has acknowledged and approved the Agreement between you
and Leonard Riggio regarding his grant of options to you of certain rights with
respect to his options to purchase 2,000,000 shares of Common Stock of the
Company.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Change of Control Payments. (a)&nbsp;If at any time during the term of
this Agreement there is a Change of Control and (i)&nbsp;your employment is
terminated by the Company for any reason (other than for Cause) or (ii)&nbsp;you
voluntarily terminate your employment for Good Cause, in either case within the
greater of two years following the Change of Control or the remaining term of
this Agreement, the Company shall pay to you the following amount: (A)&nbsp;the sum
of (x)&nbsp;your then annual salary, (y)&nbsp;your then most recent annual bonus, and (z)
the then aggregate annual dollar amount of the payments made or to be made by
the Company for purposes of providing you with the benefits set forth in
paragraphs 3.3 through 3.6 above, multiplied by (B)&nbsp;the greater of (x)&nbsp;three or
(y)&nbsp;the number of months remaining in the term of this Agreement divided by 12;
provided that the maximum amount payable pursuant to this Section&nbsp;3.8 shall be
the maximum amount payable to the Executive without triggering an excise tax
under Section&nbsp;280G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, or any
successor provision thereto. The amount due under this Section&nbsp;3.8 shall be
paid to you in one lump sum within 30&nbsp;days after the date your employment
terminates. Subject to the Section&nbsp;280G limitation referred to above, to the
extent that you are not fully vested in any retirement benefits from any
pension, profit-sharing or other retirement plan or program maintained by the
Company, the Company shall pay directly to you the difference between the
amounts which would have been paid to you had you been fully vested on the date
that your employment terminates and the amounts actually paid or payable to you
pursuant to such plans or programs. The amounts payable to you under this
Section&nbsp;3.8 shall be in lieu of any amounts payable to you under Section&nbsp;3.6
above.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;As used herein, &#147;Change of Control&#148; shall mean the occurrence of one
or more of the following events:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i)&nbsp;after the date hereof, any person, entity or &#147;group&#148; as
identified in Sections&nbsp;13(d)(3) or 14(d)(2) of the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934 (the &#147;1934 Act&#148;), other than you or any of your affiliates or
Leonard Riggio or any of his heirs or affiliates, becomes a beneficial
owner (as such term is defined in Rule&nbsp;13d-3 under the 1934 Act) directly
or indirectly of securities representing 40% or more of the total number
of votes that may be cast for the election of directors of the Company;
or</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(ii)&nbsp;within two years after a merger, consolidation, liquidation or
sale of assets involving the Company, or a contested election of a
Company director, or any combination of the foregoing, the individuals
who were directors of the Company immediately prior thereto shall cease
to constitute a majority of the Board; or</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(iii)&nbsp;within two years after a tender offer or exchange offer for
voting securities of the Company, the individuals who were directors of
the Company immediately prior thereto shall cease to constitute a
majority of the Board.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;As used herein, &#147;Good Cause&#148; shall mean the occurrence of one or more
of the following events within two years after a Change of Control:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i)&nbsp;there shall have been a material modification of your duties,
title or direct reports;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(ii)&nbsp;there shall have been a material reduction in the compensation
and benefits you receive from the Company; or</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(iii)&nbsp;the principal executive offices of the Company shall be
relocated to a location outside of the New York City metropolitan area.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-Competition.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Covenant. You agree that so long as you are employed by the Company
and for a period of two years thereafter, you will not directly or indirectly,
either as principal, agent, stockholder, employee or in any other capacity,
engage in or have a financial interest in any business that is competitive with
the businesses operated by the Company or any of its subsidiaries. The
foregoing provision shall cease to apply after: (i)&nbsp;you voluntary terminate
your employment for Good Cause within two years following a Change of Control;
or (ii)&nbsp;your employment terminates involuntarily, other than for Cause prior to
a Change of Control.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ownership of Other Securities. Nothing in paragraph 4.1 shall be
construed as denying you the right to own securities of any corporation listed
on a national securities exchange or quoted in the NASDAQ System to the extent
of an aggregate of 5% of the outstanding shares of such securities.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reasonableness. You acknowledge that the foregoing limitations are
reasonable and properly required by the Company and that in the event that any
such limitations are found to be unreasonable by a court of competent
jurisdiction, you will submit to the reduction of such limitations as the court
shall find reasonable.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Severability. If any of the restrictions in paragraph 4.1 should for
any reason whatsoever be declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction,
the validity or enforceability of the remainder of this Agreement will not be
adversely affected thereby.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equitable Relief. You acknowledge that your services to the Company
are of a unique character which give them a special value to the Company. You
further recognize that any violation of the restrictions in paragraph 4.1 may
give rise to losses or damages for which the Company cannot be reasonably or
adequately compensated in an action at law and that such violation may result
in irreparable and continuing harm to the Company. Accordingly, you agree
that, in addition to any other remedy which the Company may have at law or in
equity, the Company shall be entitled to injunctive relief to restrain any
violation by you of the restrictions in paragraph 4.1.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Indemnification. You shall be indemnified by the Company, as an
officer and director of the Company and its affiliates, against all actions,
suits, claims, legal proceedings and the like to the fullest extent permitted
by law, including advancement of expenses, partial indemnification,
indemnification following the termination of this Agreement, indemnification of
your estate and similar matters.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Miscellaneous.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Entire Agreement. This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement
between you and the Company with respect to the terms and conditions of your
employment by the Company and supersedes all prior agreements, understandings
and
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">arrangements, oral or written, between you and the Company with respect to
your employment by the Company, including the agreement between us dated as of
January&nbsp;1, 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Binding Effect; Benefits. This Agreement shall inure to the benefit
of and shall be binding upon you and the Company and our respective heirs,
legal representatives, successors and assigns.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amendments and Waivers. This Agreement may not be amended or
modified except by an instrument or instruments in writing signed by the party
against whom enforcement of any such modification or amendment is sought.
Either party may, by an instrument in writing, waive compliance by the other
party with any term or provision of this Agreement to be performed or complied
with by such other party.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assignment. Neither this Agreement nor any rights or obligations
which either party may have by reason of this Agreement shall be assignable by
either party without the prior written consent of the other party.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Litigation Expenses. The Company will pay any actual expenses for
reasonable attorneys&#146; fees and disbursements incurred by you, or your personal
representative, in seeking to obtain or enforce any right or benefit under this
Agreement, if you or your representative is the prevailing party.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No Mitigation. In the event of termination of this Agreement by you
as a result of the breach by the Company of any of its obligations hereunder,
or in the event of the termination of your employment by the Company in breach
of this Agreement, you shall not be required to seek other employment in order
to mitigate damages hereunder.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Notices. Any notice which may or must be given under this Agreement
shall be in writing and shall be personally delivered or sent by certified or
registered mail, postage prepaid, or reputable overnight courier, addressed to
you or the Company, as the case may be, at the address set forth on the first
page hereof, or to such other address as you or the Company, as the case may
be, may designate in writing in accordance with the provisions of this
paragraph.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Section and Other Headings. The section and other headings contained
in this Agreement are for reference purposes only and are not deemed to be a
part of this Agreement or to affect the meaning and interpretation of this
Agreement.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Governing Law. This Agreement shall be construed (both as to
validity and performance) and enforced in accordance with and governed by the
laws of the State of New York applicable to agreements made and to be performed
wholly within the State of New York.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Survival of Rights and Obligations. All rights and obligations of
you and the Company arising during the term of this Agreement shall continue to
have full force and effect after the termination of this Agreement unless
otherwise provided herein.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If the foregoing accurately reflects our agreement, kindly sign and return
to us the enclosed duplicate copy of this letter.
</FONT>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;13.1</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SELECTED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL DATA</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The selected consolidated financial data of Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. and its
subsidiaries (collectively, the Company) set forth on the following pages
should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and
notes included elsewhere in this report. The Company&#146;s fiscal year is comprised
of 52 or 53&nbsp;weeks, ending on the Saturday closest to the last day of January.
The Statement of Operations Data for the 52&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;1, 2003
(fiscal 2002), 52&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;2, 2002 (fiscal 2001) and 53&nbsp;weeks ended
February&nbsp;3, 2001 (fiscal 2000) and the Balance Sheet Data as of February&nbsp;1,
2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002 are derived from, and are qualified by reference to,
audited consolidated financial statements which are included elsewhere in this
report. The Statement of Operations Data for the 52&nbsp;weeks ended January&nbsp;29,
2000 (fiscal 1999) and the 52&nbsp;weeks ended January&nbsp;30, 1999 (fiscal 1998) and
the Balance Sheet Data as of February&nbsp;3, 2001, January&nbsp;29, 2000 and January&nbsp;30,
1999 are derived from audited consolidated financial statements not included in
this report. Certain prior-period amounts have been reclassified for
comparative purposes.
</FONT>
<CENTER>

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="4"><FONT size="1"><B>(Thousands of dollars, except per share data)</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>2002</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>2001</B></FONT></TD>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-2</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(8)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In fiscal 2002, the Company recorded a non-cash
charge to operating earnings to write down its
investments in Gemstar-TV Guide International,
Inc. (Gemstar) and Indigo Books &#038; Music Inc.
(Indigo) to their fair market value. In fiscal
2000, the Company recorded a non-cash charge to
adjust the carrying value of certain assets,
primarily goodwill relating to the purchase of B.
Dalton and other mall-bookstore assets.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(9)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Interest expense for fiscal 2002, 2001, 2000,
1999 and 1998 is net of interest income of
$3,499, $1,319, $939, $1,449 and $976,
respectively.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(10)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;12, 1998, the Company and
Bertelsmann AG (Bertelsmann) completed the
formation of a limited liability company to
operate the online retail bookselling operations
of the Company&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary,
barnesandnoble.com inc., which had begun
operations in fiscal 1997. As a result of the
formation of barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes &#038;
Noble.com), the Company began accounting for its
interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com under the equity
method of accounting as of the beginning of
fiscal 1998. Fiscal 1998 reflects a 100&nbsp;percent
equity interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com for the
first three quarters ended October&nbsp;31, 1998 (also
the effective date of the limited liability
company agreement), and a 50&nbsp;percent equity
interest beginning on November&nbsp;1, 1998 through
the end of the fiscal year. As a result of the
initial public offering (IPO)&nbsp;for the Barnes &#038;
Noble.com business on May&nbsp;25, 1999, the Company
and Bertelsmann each retained a 40&nbsp;percent
interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. From the date of
the IPO through the end of fiscal 2002, the
Company&#146;s ownership interest has varied from 40
percent to 36&nbsp;percent.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(11)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">As a result of the formation of the limited
liability company Barnes &#038; Noble.com, the Company
recognized a pre-tax gain during fiscal 1998 in
the amount of $126,435, of which $63,759 has been
recognized in earnings based on the $75,000
received directly from Bertelsmann and $62,676
($36,351 after taxes) has been reflected in
additional paid-in capital based on the Company&#146;s
share of the incremental equity of the joint
venture resulting from the $150,000 Bertelsmann
contribution. As a result of the Barnes &#038;
Noble.com IPO, the Company recorded an increase
in additional paid-in capital of $200,272
($116,158 after taxes) representing the Company&#146;s
incremental share in the equity in Barnes &#038;
Noble.com. In addition, the Company recognized a
pre-tax gain of $25,000 in fiscal 1999 as a
result of cash received in connection with the
joint venture agreement with Bertelsmann.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

decrease in value in certain of its equity
investments occurred which was other than
temporary. As a result, other expense of $16,498

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-4</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s fiscal year is comprised of 52 or 53&nbsp;weeks, ending on the
Saturday closest to the last day of January. As used in this section, &#147;fiscal
2003&#148; represents the 52&nbsp;weeks ending January&nbsp;31, 2004, &#147;fiscal 2002&#148; represents
the 52&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;1, 2003, &#147;fiscal 2001&#148; represents the 52&nbsp;weeks
ended February&nbsp;2, 2002 and &#147;fiscal 2000&#148; represents the 53&nbsp;weeks ended February
3, 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>General</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (Barnes &#038; Noble or the Company), the nation&#146;s largest
bookseller<SUP>1</SUP>, as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 operates 886 bookstores and 1,231
video-game and entertainment-software stores. Of the 886 bookstores, 628
operate under the Barnes &#038; Noble Booksellers, Bookstop and Bookstar trade names
(47 of which were opened in fiscal 2002) and 258 operate under the B. Dalton
Bookseller, Doubleday Book Shops and Scribner&#146;s Bookstore trade names. Through
its approximate 38&nbsp;percent interest in barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes &#038;
Noble.com), the Company is one of the largest sellers of books on the Internet.
The Company, through its approximate 63&nbsp;percent interest in GameStop Corp., is
the nation&#146;s largest video-game and PC-entertainment software specialty
retailer, operating 1,231 video-game and entertainment-software stores under
the GameStop, Babbage&#146;s, Software Etc. and FuncoLand trade names, a Web site,
gamestop.com, and <I>Game Informer</I>, one of the largest multi-platform video-game
magazines, with circulation of over one million subscribers. The Company
employed approximately 50,000 full- and part-time employees as of February&nbsp;1,
2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes
&#038; Noble is the nation&#146;s largest operator of
bookstores<SUP>1</SUP> with 628
Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores located in 49 states and the District of Columbia as
of February&nbsp;1, 2003. With more than 35&nbsp;years of bookselling experience,
management has a strong sense of customers&#146; changing needs and the Company
leads book retailing with a &#147;community store&#148; concept. Barnes &#038; Noble&#146;s typical
bookstore offers a comprehensive title base, a caf&#233;, a children&#146;s section, a
music department, a magazine section and a calendar of ongoing events,
including author appearances and children&#146;s activities, that make each Barnes &#038;
Noble bookstore an active part of its community.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores range in size from 10,000 to 60,000 square feet
depending upon market size, and each store features an authoritative selection
of books, ranging from 60,000 to 200,000 titles. The comprehensive title
selection is diverse and reflects local interests. In addition, Barnes &#038; Noble
emphasizes books published by small and independent publishers and university
presses. Bestsellers represent only three percent of Barnes &#038; Noble bookstore
sales. Complementing this extensive on-site selection, all Barnes &#038; Noble
bookstores provide customers with access to the millions of books available to
online shoppers while offering an option to have the book sent to the store or
shipped directly to the customer. All Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores are equipped
with the BookMaster in-store operating system, which enhances the Company&#146;s
merchandise-replenishment system, resulting in high in-stock positions and
productivity at the store level through efficiencies in receiving, cashiering
and returns processing.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal 2002, the Company added 1.0&nbsp;million square feet to the
Barnes &#038; Noble bookstore base, bringing the total square footage to 15.2
million square feet, a seven percent increase over the prior year. Barnes &#038;
Noble bookstores contributed approximately 91&nbsp;percent of the Company&#146;s total
bookstore sales in fiscal 2002. The Company plans to open between 35 and 40
Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores in fiscal 2003, which are expected to average 25,000
square feet in size.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At the end of fiscal 2002, the Company operated 258 B. Dalton bookstores
in 44 states and the District of Columbia. B. Dalton bookstores employ
merchandising strategies that target the mainstream</FONT>

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="100%"><FONT size="2"><SUP>1</SUP> Based upon sales reported in trade publications and public filings.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-5</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> consumer book market,
offering a wide range of bestsellers and general-interest titles. Most B.
Dalton bookstores range in size from 2,000 to 6,000 square feet, and while they
are appropriate to the size of adjacent mall tenants, the opening of book
superstores in nearby locations continues to have a significant adverse impact
on B. Dalton bookstores.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is continuing to execute a strategy to maximize returns from
its B. Dalton bookstores in response to declining sales attributable primarily
to book superstore competition. Part of the Company&#146;s strategy has been to
close underperforming stores, which has resulted in the closing of between 35
and 90 B. Dalton bookstores per year since 1989.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has a 38&nbsp;percent ownership interest in Barnes &#038;
Noble.com, a leading internet-based retailer of books, music, DVD/video and
online courses. Since opening its online store (www.bn.com) in March 1997,
Barnes &#038; Noble.com has attracted more than 13.6&nbsp;million customers in 232
countries. Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s bookstore includes the largest in-stock
selection of in-print book titles with access to approximately one million
titles for immediate delivery, supplemented by more than 30&nbsp;million listings
from its nationwide network of out-of-print, rare and used book dealers.
Barnes &#038; Noble.com offers its customers fast delivery, easy and secure ordering
and rich editorial content.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;According to Jupiter Media Metrix, in December 2002, Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s
Web site was the ninth most-trafficked shopping site and was among the top 50
largest Web properties on the Internet. Co-marketing agreements with major Web
portals such as AOL, Yahoo! and MSN as well as content sites have extended
Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s brand and increased consumer exposure to its site. Barnes
&#038; Noble.com has also established a network of remote virtual storefronts across
the Internet by creating direct links with more than 176,000 affiliate Web
sites.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble further differentiates its product offerings from those of
its competitors by publishing books under its own imprints. The Company,
through its January 2003 acquisition of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
(Sterling), is one of the top 25 publishers in the nation and the industry&#146;s
leading publisher of how-to books. Sterling has an active list of more than
4,500 owned and distributed titles, and publishes and distributes more than
1,000 new titles annually. As a leading publisher of how-to books, Sterling
has strength in art technique, gardening, cooking, health, crafts, puzzle and
game, woodworking and house and home. With the addition of the Sterling
titles, the Company has publishing or distribution rights to nearly 10,000
titles and offers customers high quality books at exceptional values, while
generating attractive gross margins.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company acquired Babbage&#146;s Etc. and Funco, Inc. in October 1999 and
June 2000, respectively. Through a corporate restructuring, Babbage&#146;s Etc.
became a wholly owned subsidiary of Funco, Inc. and the name of Funco, Inc. was
changed to GameStop, Inc. In February 2002, the Company completed an initial
public offering for its GameStop subsidiary. The Company retained an
approximate 63&nbsp;percent interest in GameStop. GameStop is the nation&#146;s largest
video-game and PC-entertainment software specialty retailer, operating 1,231
video-game and entertainment-software stores located in 49 states, Puerto Rico
and Guam. The video-game and entertainment-software stores range in size from
500 to 5,000 square feet (averaging 1,500 square feet) depending upon market
demographics. Stores feature video-game hardware and software,
PC-entertainment software and a multitude of accessories. GameStop operates
stores under the GameStop, Babbage&#146;s, Software Etc. and FuncoLand trade names,
a Web site,
gamestop.com, and <I>Game Informer </I>magazine (collectively, GameStop or Video Game
&#038; Entertainment Software).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Critical Accounting Policies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-6</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">discusses the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements, which
have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements require
management to make estimates and assumptions in certain circumstances that
affect amounts reported in the accompanying consolidated financial statements
and related footnotes. In preparing these financial statements, management has
made its best estimates and judgments of certain amounts included in the
financial statements, giving due consideration to materiality. The Company does
not believe there is a great likelihood that materially different amounts would
be reported related to the accounting policies described below. However,
application of these accounting policies involves the exercise of judgment and
use of assumptions as to future uncertainties and, as a result, actual results
could differ from these estimates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and Goodwill</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s long-lived assets include property and equipment and
goodwill. At February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company had $622.3&nbsp;million of property and
equipment, net of accumulated depreciation, and $438.6&nbsp;million of goodwill, net
of amortization, accounting for approximately 35.4% of the Company&#146;s total
assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company periodically reviews its property and equipment under the
newly issued accounting pronouncement Statement of Financial Accounting
Standards (SFAS)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of
Long-Lived Assets,&#148; whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that
their carrying amounts may not be recoverable or their depreciation periods
should be accelerated. Factors that the Company considers important which
could trigger a review include the following:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant changes in the manner of use of the assets</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant changes in the strategy of the overall business</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant underperformance relative to expected historical
or projected future operating results</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Recoverability is assessed based on several factors, including
management&#146;s intentions with respect to its stores and those stores&#146; projected
undiscounted cash flows. Assumptions underlying such projected cash flows
include historical experience of stores, competitive environment, purchasing
trends and projected demographics in the areas.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If it is determined that the carrying value of long-lived assets may not
be recoverable, the Company measures impairment based on the present values of
the projected cash flows using a discount rate determined by the Company&#146;s
management to be commensurate with the risk involved.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other
Intangible Assets&#148;. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 requires that purchased goodwill and certain
indefinite-lived intangibles no longer be amortized, but instead be tested
for impairment at least annually. As a result of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;142, the
Company ceased amortization of goodwill beginning February&nbsp;3, 2002. Prior to
the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, the Company amortized goodwill on a
straight-line basis over 30 to 40&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;142 prescribes a two-step process for impairment testing of
goodwill. The first step of this test, used to identify potential
impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying
amount, including goodwill. The second step (if necessary) measures the
amount of the impairment. Using the guidance in SFAS No.&nbsp;142, the Company
has determined that it has two reporting units, bookstores and video-game and
entertainment-software stores. The Company completed its initial impairment
test on the goodwill in the second quarter of fiscal 2002 and its annual
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-7</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">impairment test in November 2002. Both tests indicated that the fair value
of the reporting units exceeded that reporting unit&#146;s carrying amount;
accordingly, the second testing phase was not necessary. The Company has
noted no subsequent indicators that would require testing goodwill for
impairment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Closed Store Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon a formal decision to close or relocate a store, the Company charges
unrecoverable costs to expense. Such costs include the net book value of
abandoned fixtures and leasehold improvements and, when a store is closed, a
provision for future lease obligations, net of expected sublease recoveries.
Costs associated with store closings of $10.1&nbsp;million, $9.8&nbsp;million and $5.0
million during fiscal 2002, fiscal 2001 and fiscal 2000, respectively, are
included in selling and administrative expenses in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-8</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-9</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">of $25,328. Fiscal
2001 operating profit is net of legal and
settlement expenses of $4,500. Fiscal 2000
operating profit is net of a non-cash
impairment charge of $106,833.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Comparable store sales for Barnes &#038; Noble
stores are determined using stores open at
least 15&nbsp;months, due to the high sales volume
associated with grand openings. Comparable
store sales for B. Dalton and GameStop stores
are determined using stores open at least 12
months.</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">2.2</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(0.7</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>52 Weeks Ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 Compared with 52 Weeks Ended February&nbsp;2, 2002</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Sales</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s sales increased $398.9&nbsp;million or 8.2% during fiscal 2002 to
$5.269&nbsp;billion from $4.870&nbsp;billion during fiscal 2001. Contributing to this
improvement was an increase of $231.4&nbsp;million from Video Game &#038; Entertainment
Software store sales. Fiscal 2002 sales from Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores, which
contributed 67.8% of total sales or 91.3% of total bookstore sales, increased
6.4% to $3.575&nbsp;billion from $3.359&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in bookstore sales was primarily attributable to the 47 new
Barnes &#038; Noble stores opened during fiscal 2002. This increase was partially
offset by declining sales of B. Dalton, due to 47 store closings and a
comparable store sales decline of (6.4%) in fiscal 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop sales during fiscal 2002 increased to $1.353&nbsp;billion from $1.121
billion during fiscal 2001. This increase in sales was primarily attributable
to the 11.4% growth in GameStop comparable store sales and sales from the 210
new GameStop stores opened during fiscal 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Cost of Sales and Occupancy</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s cost of sales and occupancy includes costs such as rental
expense, common area
maintenance, merchant association dues and lease-required advertising.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-11</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of sales and occupancy increased $295.8&nbsp;million, or 8.3%, to $3.856
billion in fiscal 2002 from $3.560&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2001, primarily due to
growth in the Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment. The Company&#146;s gross
margin rate decreased slightly to 26.8% in fiscal 2002 from 26.9% in fiscal
2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Selling and Administrative Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling and administrative expenses increased $60.8&nbsp;million, or 6.7%, to
$965.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from $904.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001, primarily due
to the increase in bookstore expenses from the opening of 47 Barnes &#038; Noble
stores in fiscal 2002 and to the growth in the Video Game &#038; Entertainment
Software segment. Selling and administrative expenses decreased to 18.3% of
sales in fiscal 2002 from 18.6% in fiscal 2001. This decrease was primarily
attributable to the lower selling and administrative expenses, as a percentage
of sales in the Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Legal Settlement Expense</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $4.5&nbsp;million in
connection with a lawsuit brought by the American Booksellers Association and
26 independent bookstores. The charges included a settlement of $2.4&nbsp;million
paid to the plaintiffs and approximately $2.1&nbsp;million in legal expenses
incurred by the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Depreciation and Amortization</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $0.9&nbsp;million, or 0.6%, to $148.7
million in fiscal 2002 from $147.8&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. The increase was
primarily the result of the increase in depreciation related to the 47 new
Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores opened during fiscal 2002. This increase was
partially offset by the result of the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 in fiscal
2002, whereby goodwill is no longer amortized but is reviewed for impairment at
least annually.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Pre-Opening Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pre-opening expenses increased in fiscal 2002 to $10.2&nbsp;million from $8.0
million in fiscal 2001. The increase in pre-opening expenses was primarily the
result of opening 47 new Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores and 210 new GameStop stores
during fiscal 2002, compared with 40 new Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores and 74 new
GameStop stores during fiscal 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Impairment Charge</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company deemed the decline in
value in its available-for-sale securities in Gemstar-TV Guide International,
Inc. (Gemstar) and Indigo Books &#038; Music Inc. (Indigo) to be other than
temporary. The investments had been carried at fair market value with
unrealized gains and losses included in shareholders&#146; equity. Events such as
Gemstar&#146;s largest shareholder taking an impairment charge for its investment,
the precipitous decline in the stock price subsequent to the abrupt resignation
of one of its senior executives, the questioning of aggressive revenue
recognition policies and the filing of a class action lawsuit against Gemstar,
were among the items which led to management&#146;s decision to record an impairment
for its investment in Gemstar of nearly $24.0&nbsp;million (before taxes). The
Company&#146;s decision to record an impairment charge for its investment in
Indigo was based on a review of Indigo&#146;s financial condition and historical
share trading data. As a result of these decisions, the Company recorded a
non-cash impairment charge to operating earnings of $25.3
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-12</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">million ($14.9
million after taxes) to reclassify the accumulated unrealized losses and to
write down the investments to their current fair market value at the close of
business on May&nbsp;4, 2002. The investment in Gemstar was sold in the second
quarter of fiscal 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Operating Profit</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating profit increased to $264.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from $245.8
million in fiscal 2001. Operating profit increased to $289.4&nbsp;million, before
the effect of the $25.3&nbsp;million impairment charge during fiscal 2002, from
$250.3&nbsp;million, before the effect of the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense
during fiscal 2001. Bookstore operating profit decreased 6.4% to $202.4
million, before the effect of the $25.3&nbsp;million impairment charge from $216.2
million, before the effect of the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense,
primarily attributable to lower comparable store sales. Bookstore operating
margin decreased to 5.2% of sales during fiscal 2002, before the effect of the
impairment charge, from 5.8% of sales during fiscal 2001, before the effect of
the legal settlement expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Interest Expense, Net and Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense, net of interest income, and amortization of deferred
financing fees, decreased $14.8&nbsp;million to $21.5&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from
$36.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. The decrease was primarily the result of reduced
borrowings under the Company&#146;s senior credit facility due to the pay down of
debt with proceeds from the GameStop IPO.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Equity in Net Loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s share in the net loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com, based on an
approximate 36&nbsp;percent equity interest, was $26.8&nbsp;million and $88.4&nbsp;million in
fiscal 2002 and fiscal 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other Expense, Primarily Losses Attributable to Equity-Method Investments</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company determined that a decrease in value in certain
of its equity investments occurred which was other than temporary. As a
result, other expense of $16.5&nbsp;million during fiscal 2002 included the
recognition of losses of $11.5&nbsp;million in excess of what would otherwise have
been recognized by application of the equity method in accordance with
Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;18, &#147;The Equity Method of Accounting
for Investments in Common Stock.&#148; The $16.5&nbsp;million loss in other expense was
primarily comprised of $8.5&nbsp;million attributable to iUniverse.com, $5.1&nbsp;million
attributable to <I>BOOK&#174; </I>magazine and $2.4&nbsp;million attributable to enews, inc.
Other expense of $11.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 was due to $4.0&nbsp;million in equity
losses in iUniverse.com, $2.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in <I>BOOK&#174; </I>magazine and
$5.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in enews, inc., partially offset by a one-time
gain of $0.3&nbsp;million from the partial sale of Indigo.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Provision for Income Taxes</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble&#146;s effective tax rate in fiscal 2002 decreased to 40.25
percent compared with 41.50&nbsp;percent during fiscal 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-13</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Minority Interest</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal 2002, minority interest for GameStop was $19.1&nbsp;million based
on a 36.5% basic weighted average ownership interest.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Earnings</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the factors discussed above, the Company reported
consolidated net earnings of $99.9&nbsp;million (or $1.39 per share) during fiscal
2002 compared with net earnings of $64.0&nbsp;million (or $0.94 per share) during
fiscal 2001. Components of diluted earnings per share are as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Consolidated EPS</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">1.39</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">0.94</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>52 Weeks Ended February&nbsp;2, 2002 Compared with 53 Weeks Ended February&nbsp;3, 2001</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Sales</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s sales increased $494.6&nbsp;million or 11.3% during fiscal 2001
to $4.870&nbsp;billion from $4.376&nbsp;billion during fiscal 2000. Contributing to this
improvement was an increase of $363.8&nbsp;million from Video Game &#038; Entertainment
Software store sales. Fiscal 2001 sales from Barnes &#038; Noble bookstores, which
contributed 69.0% of total sales or 89.6% of total bookstore sales, increased
6.0% to $3.359&nbsp;billion from $3.170&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in bookstore sales was primarily attributable to the 2.7%
growth in Barnes &#038; Noble comparable store sales and sales from the 40 new
Barnes &#038; Noble stores opened during fiscal 2001. This increase was partially
offset by declining sales of B. Dalton, due to 35 store closings and a
comparable store sales decline of (3.7%) in fiscal 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop sales during fiscal 2001 increased to $1.121&nbsp;billion from $757.6
million during fiscal 2000. This increase in sales was primarily attributable
to the 32.0% growth in the GameStop comparable
store sales and sales from the 74 new GameStop stores opened during fiscal
2001. This increase was also attributable to the inclusion of a full year of
Funco, Inc. sales in fiscal 2001 compared with sales for
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-14</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">approximately one-half
of fiscal 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Cost of Sales and Occupancy</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s cost of sales and occupancy includes costs such as rental
expense, common area maintenance, merchant association dues and lease-required
advertising.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of sales and occupancy increased $390.3&nbsp;million, or 12.3%, to $3.560
billion in fiscal 2001 from $3.170&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2000, primarily due to
growth in the Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment. The Company&#146;s gross
margin rate decreased to 26.9% in fiscal 2001 from 27.6% in fiscal 2000. This
decrease was primarily attributable to the lower gross margins in the Video
Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment and slightly lower gross margins in the
bookstore segment due to discounts related to the Readers&#146; Advantage&#153;
program.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Selling and Administrative Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling and administrative expenses increased $91.3&nbsp;million, or 11.2%, to
$904.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 from $813.0&nbsp;million in fiscal 2000, primarily due
to growth in the Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment and the increase
in bookstore expenses from the opening of 40 Barnes &#038; Noble stores in fiscal
2001. Selling and administrative expenses remained unchanged at 18.6% of sales
during fiscal 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Legal Settlement Expense</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $4.5&nbsp;million in
connection with a lawsuit brought by the American Booksellers Association and
26 independent bookstores. The charges included a settlement of $2.4&nbsp;million to
be paid to plaintiffs and approximately $2.1&nbsp;million in legal expenses incurred
by the Company during the first quarter.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Depreciation and Amortization</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $3.1&nbsp;million, or 2.1%, to $147.8
million in fiscal 2001 from $144.8&nbsp;million in fiscal 2000. The increase was
primarily the result of the increase in depreciation and amortization in the
Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software segment offset by the reduction in
depreciable assets in small-format mall bookstores due to the impairment charge
recorded in fiscal 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Pre-Opening Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pre-opening expenses increased in fiscal 2001 to $8.0&nbsp;million from $7.7
million in fiscal 2000. Due to management&#146;s expense control efforts,
pre-opening expenses increased only slightly while opening 40 Barnes &#038; Noble
stores and 74 new GameStop stores in fiscal 2001, compared with 32 new Barnes &#038;
Noble stores and 65 new GameStop stores during fiscal 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Operating Profit</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating profit increased to $245.8&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 from $133.8
million in fiscal 2000.
Operating profit increased $9.6&nbsp;million to $250.3&nbsp;million, before the effect of
the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense during fiscal 2001, from $240.7
million, before the effect of the $106.8&nbsp;million impairment charge during
fiscal 2000. Bookstore operating profit decreased 7.9% to $216.2&nbsp;million,
before the effect of the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense, from $234.6
million, before the effect of the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-15</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">$106.8&nbsp;million impairment charge, primarily
attributable to lower comparable store sales and lower gross margins due to
discounts related to the Readers&#146; Advantage&#153; program. Bookstore operating
margin decreased to 5.8% of sales during fiscal 2001, before the effect of the
legal settlement expense, from 6.5% of sales during fiscal 2000, before the
effect of the impairment charge.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Interest Expense, Net and Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense, net of interest income, and amortization of deferred
financing fees, decreased $17.2&nbsp;million to $36.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 from
$53.5&nbsp;million in fiscal 2000. The decrease was primarily the result of reduced
borrowings due to effective working capital management and lower interest rates
on the Company&#146;s outstanding debt, partially through the issuance of the
Company&#146;s convertible subordinated notes sold in March 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Equity in Net Loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2000, Barnes &#038; Noble.com acquired Fatbrain.com, Inc.
(Fatbrain), the third largest online bookseller. Barnes &#038; Noble.com issued
shares of its common stock to Fatbrain shareholders. As a result of this
merger, the Company and Bertelsmann each retained an approximate 36&nbsp;percent
interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. Accordingly, the Company&#146;s share in the net
loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com is based on an approximate 40&nbsp;percent equity
interest from the beginning of fiscal 2000 through November 2000 and
approximately 36&nbsp;percent thereafter. The Company&#146;s equity in the net loss of
Barnes &#038; Noble.com for fiscal 2001 and fiscal 2000 was $88.4&nbsp;million and $103.9
million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other Expense</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense of $11.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 was due to $4.0&nbsp;million in
equity losses in iUniverse.com, $2.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in <I>BOOK&#174;</I>
magazine and $5.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in enews, inc., partially offset by
a one-time gain of $0.3&nbsp;million from the partial sale of Indigo. Other expense
of $9.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2000 was primarily due to the equity losses of
iUniverse.com, partially offset by a one-time gain of $0.3&nbsp;million from the
partial sale of iUniverse.com.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Provision for Income Taxes</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble&#146;s effective tax rate in fiscal 2001 decreased to 41.5
percent compared with (57.5) percent during fiscal 2000. The fiscal 2001
decrease was primarily related to the goodwill write-down associated with the
impairment charge, which provided no tax benefit in fiscal 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-16</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Earnings (Loss)</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the factors discussed above, the Company reported
consolidated net earnings of $64.0&nbsp;million (or $0.94 per share) during fiscal
2001 compared with a net loss of ($52.0) million (or ($0.81) per share) during
fiscal 2000. Components of diluted earnings per share are as follows:
</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
