</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Seasonality</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s business, like that of many retailers, is seasonal, with the
major portion of sales and operating profit realized during the quarter which
includes the holiday selling season.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Working capital requirements are generally at their highest in the
Company&#146;s fiscal quarter ending on or about January&nbsp;31 due to the higher
payments to vendors for holiday season merchandise purchases. In addition, the
Company&#146;s sales and merchandise inventory levels will fluctuate from quarter to
quarter as a result of the number and timing of new store openings, as well as
the amount and timing of sales contributed by new stores.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows from operating activities, funds available under its revolving
credit facility and short-term vendor financing continue to provide the Company
with liquidity and capital resources for store expansion, seasonal working
capital requirements and capital investments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2002, the Company completed an initial public offering (IPO)
for its GameStop subsidiary, raising $250.0&nbsp;million in cash for the Company
(which was used to pay down debt) and $98.0&nbsp;million in net proceeds for
GameStop. The Company has retained an approximate 63&nbsp;percent interest in
GameStop.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Flow</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows provided from operating activities were $329.0&nbsp;million, $457.4
million and $80.5&nbsp;million during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. In
fiscal 2002, the decrease in cash flows from
operating activities was primarily attributable to a weaker-than-expected
holiday season, as well as the increase in inventory due to the Reno
distribution center becoming fully operational. In fiscal 2001, the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-17</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">increase in
cash flows from operating activities was primarily attributable to increased
accounts payable leverage and improvement in net earnings. In fiscal 2000, the
decrease in cash flows from operating activities was primarily attributable to
a weaker-than-expected holiday season which resulted in lower net earnings and
an increase in standing inventory as well as an increase in prepaid rent due to
the fiscal year-end date.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Retail earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization
(EBITDA)&nbsp;increased $0.9&nbsp;million or 0.2% to $393.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from
$392.2&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. Total debt to retail EBITDA improved to 0.76
times in fiscal 2002 from 1.14 times in fiscal 2001, primarily due to decreased
borrowings under the Company&#146;s senior credit facility. The reduced debt, which
was accomplished during a period of 8.2% sales growth and an 8.6% increase in
merchandise inventories, was primarily attributable to the proceeds received
from the GameStop IPO. The weighted-average age per square foot of the
Company&#146;s 628 Barnes &#038; Noble stores was 5.8&nbsp;years as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and is
expected to increase to approximately 6.5&nbsp;years by January&nbsp;31, 2004. As the
Barnes &#038; Noble stores continue to mature, and as the number of new stores
opened during the fiscal year decreases as a percentage of the existing store
base, the increasing operating profits of Barnes &#038; Noble stores are expected to
generate a greater portion of the cash flows required for working capital,
including new store inventories, capital expenditures and other initiatives.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since the fiscal 1999 Barnes &#038; Noble.com Inc. IPO, retail cash flows have
been fully available to support the Company&#146;s working capital requirements. In
the future, the Company may provide additional funding to Barnes &#038; Noble.com.
As of February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company had an aggregate receivable of $55.2
million from Barnes &#038; Noble.com related to its supply and service agreements.
Barnes &#038; Noble.com had cash, cash equivalents and short-term marketable
securities of $70.1&nbsp;million as of its year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, an amount
sufficient to cover this payable due to the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Capital Structure</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Strong cash flows from operations and a continued emphasis on working
capital management strengthened the Company&#146;s balance sheet in fiscal 2002.
Shareholders&#146; equity increased 15.7% to $1.028&nbsp;billion as of February&nbsp;1, 2003,
from $888.1&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;2, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company obtained a $500.0&nbsp;million three-year senior
revolving credit facility (the Facility) with a syndicate of banks led by Fleet
National Bank as administrative agent. The Facility, which expires in May 2005,
replaced the Company&#146;s $850.0&nbsp;million senior credit facility. The Facility
permits borrowings at various interest-rate options based on the prime rate or
London Interbank Offer Rate (LIBOR)&nbsp;plus applicable margin depending upon the
level of the Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage ratio. The Company&#146;s fixed charge
coverage is calculated as the ratio of earnings before interest, taxes,
depreciation, amortization and rents to interest plus rents. In addition, the
Facility requires the Company to pay a commitment fee of 0.25&nbsp;percent, which
fee varies based upon the Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage ratio, calculated as
a percentage of the unused portion. The Company is required to pay utilization
fees of 0.125&nbsp;percent or 0.25&nbsp;percent on all outstanding loans under the
Facility if the aggregate outstanding loans are greater than 33&nbsp;percent and 66
percent, respectively, of the aggregate amount of the Facility.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A portion of the Facility, not to exceed $100.0&nbsp;million, is available for
the issuance of letters of credit. Also, under certain circumstances, the
Company may be permitted to increase the size of the Facility
to an amount not to exceed $600.0&nbsp;million and/or to extend the term of the
Facility by one additional year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The amount outstanding under the Facility has been classified as long-term
debt in the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-18</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">accompanying consolidated balance sheets due to both the Company&#146;s
intent and ability to maintain principal amounts.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company issued $300.0&nbsp;million of 5.25&nbsp;percent
convertible subordinated notes due March&nbsp;15, 2009. The notes are convertible
into the Company&#146;s common stock at a conversion price of $32.512 per share.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2000, the Company obtained an additional $100.0&nbsp;million senior
unsecured seasonal credit facility (seasonal credit facility) with a syndicate
of banks led by The Chase Manhattan Bank. The seasonal credit facility, which
matured on January&nbsp;31, 2001, permitted for borrowings at an interest rate based
on LIBOR. In addition, the agreement required the Company to pay a commitment
fee of 0.375&nbsp;percent of the unused portion. The seasonal credit facility was
guaranteed by all restricted subsidiaries of Barnes &#038; Noble.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Borrowings under the Company&#146;s convertible subordinated notes, senior and
seasonal credit facilities averaged $377.3&nbsp;million, $689.3&nbsp;million and $697.8
million and peaked at $490.3&nbsp;million, $870.0&nbsp;million and $918.7&nbsp;million during
fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. The ratio of debt to equity improved
significantly to 0.29:1.00 as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 from 0.51:1.00 as of February
2, 2002, primarily due to decreased borrowings under the Company&#146;s senior
credit facility.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest rate swap agreements are valued based on market quotes obtained
from dealers. The estimated fair value of the interest rate swaps liability was
$0.0&nbsp;million and $2.3&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002,
respectively. The interest rate swaps are included as a component of other
long-term liabilities.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Capital Investment</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital expenditures totaled $179.5&nbsp;million, $168.8&nbsp;million and $134.3
million during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Capital expenditures
in fiscal 2003, primarily for the opening of between 35 and 40 new Barnes &#038;
Noble stores and between 235 and 265 GameStop stores, are expected to be
between $140&nbsp;million and $160&nbsp;million, although commitment to many of such
expenditures has not yet been made.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on current operating levels and the store expansion planned for the
next fiscal year, management believes cash flows generated from operating
activities, short-term vendor financing and borrowing capacity under its
revolving credit facility will be sufficient to meet the Company&#146;s working
capital and debt service requirements, and support the development of its
short- and long-term strategies for at least the next 12&nbsp;months.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Board of Directors authorized a common stock
repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250.0&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s
common shares. As of February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company has repurchased 8,502,700
shares at a cost of approximately $181.4&nbsp;million under this program. The
repurchased shares are held in treasury.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company announced its intent to purchase up to $10.0
million of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A Common Stock in the open market or
through privately negotiated transactions. As of
February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company purchased approximately 1.7&nbsp;million shares
of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A Common Stock for $1.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-19</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Certain Relationships and Related Transactions</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company believes that the transactions and agreements discussed below
(including renewals of any existing agreements) between the Company and its
affiliates are at least as favorable to the Company as could be obtained from
unaffiliated parties. The Board of Directors and the Audit Committee are
designated to approve in advance any new proposed transaction or agreement with
affiliates and will utilize procedures in evaluating the terms and provisions
of such proposed transaction or agreement as are appropriate in light of the
fiduciary duties of directors under Delaware law.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases space for its executive offices in properties in which
Leonard Riggio, Chairman of the Board and principal stockholder of Barnes &#038;
Noble, has a minority interest. The space was rented at an aggregate annual
rent including real estate taxes of approximately $4.0&nbsp;million, $4.0&nbsp;million
and $3.4&nbsp;million in fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Rent per
square foot is approximately $28.00, which is below market.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases a 75,000-square-foot office/warehouse from a
partnership in which Leonard Riggio has a 50&nbsp;percent interest, pursuant to a
lease expiring in 2023. Pursuant to such lease, the Company paid $0.8&nbsp;million,
$0.5&nbsp;million and $0.6&nbsp;million in fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases retail space in a building in which Barnes &#038; Noble
College Bookstores, Inc. (B&#038;N College), a company owned by Leonard Riggio,
subleases space for its executive offices from the Company. Occupancy costs
allocated by the Company to B&#038;N College for this space totaled $0.8&nbsp;million<B>,</B>
$0.7&nbsp;million and $0.7&nbsp;million for fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively. The amount paid by B&#038;N College to the Company approximates the
cost per square foot paid by the Company to its unaffiliated third-party
landlord.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company subleased warehouse space from Barnes &#038; Noble.com in Reno,
Nevada. The Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com $0.3&nbsp;million, $1.8&nbsp;million and $1.4
million for such subleased space during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively. Additionally, in January 2001, the Company purchased $6.2
million of warehouse equipment (valued at original cost) from Barnes &#038;
Noble.com&#146;s Reno warehouse. In January 2002, Barnes &#038; Noble.com determined it
could not effectively utilize the full capacity of the Reno, Nevada
distribution center. As a result, Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s Board of Directors
approved the transfer of the Reno warehouse lease and the sale of inventory
located in Reno to the Company. The Company purchased the inventory from
Barnes &#038; Noble.com at cost for $9.9&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company spent
$1.8&nbsp;million to refurbish the facility. The Company&#146;s Board of Directors also
approved the Company&#146;s assumption of the lease, which expires in 2010, and the
hiring of all of the employees at the Reno facility. The Reno lease assignment
and the transfer of the Reno facility to the Company was completed in April
2002. The Company intends to use the Reno facility to facilitate distribution
to its current and future West Coast stores. In connection with the transition,
Barnes &#038; Noble.com agreed to pay one-half of the rent for the Reno facility
through December&nbsp;31, 2002. Barnes &#038; Noble.com paid $0.9&nbsp;million in relation to
these expenses for fiscal year 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company subleases to Barnes &#038; Noble.com approximately one-third of a
300,000-square-foot warehouse facility located in New Jersey. The Company has
received from Barnes &#038; Noble.com $0.5&nbsp;million annually for such subleased space
during each of the fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000. The amount paid by Barnes
&#038; Noble.com to the Company approximates the cost per square foot paid by the
Company as a tenant pursuant to the lease of the space from an unaffiliated
third party.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has entered into an agreement (the Supply Agreement) with
Barnes &#038; Noble.com whereby the Company charges Barnes &#038; Noble.com the costs
associated with such purchases plus
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-20</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">incremental overhead incurred by the
Company in connection with providing such inventory. The Supply Agreement is
subject to certain termination provisions. Barnes &#038; Noble.com purchased $108.3
million, $119.3&nbsp;million and $110.5&nbsp;million of merchandise from the Company
during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively, and Barnes &#038; Noble.com expects
to source purchases through the Company in the future.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has entered into agreements whereby Barnes &#038; Noble.com
receives various services from the Company, including, among others, services
for payroll processing, benefits administration, insurance (property, casualty,
medical, dental, life, etc.), tax, traffic, fulfillment and telecommunications.
In accordance with the terms of such agreements, the Company has received, and
expects to continue to receive, fees in an amount equal to the direct costs
plus incremental expenses associated with providing such services. The Company
received $3.5&nbsp;million, $5.5&nbsp;million and $1.7&nbsp;million for such services during
fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate receivable (which is historically settled within 60&nbsp;days)
from Barnes &#038; Noble.com in connection with the agreements described above was
$55.2&nbsp;million and $47.2&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company and Barnes &#038; Noble.com commenced a marketing program in
November 2000, whereby a customer purchases a &#147;Readers&#146; Advantage&#153; card&#148; for
an annual membership fee of $25.00 which is non-refundable after the first 30
days of the membership term. With this card, customers can receive discounts
of 10&nbsp;percent on all Company purchases and 5&nbsp;percent on all Barnes &#038; Noble.com
purchases. The Company and Barnes &#038; Noble.com have agreed to share the
expenses, net of revenue from the sale of the cards, related to this program in
proportion to the discounts customers receive on purchases with each company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2002, the Company through its wholly owned subsidiary, Marketing
Services (Minnesota) Corp., entered into an agreement with Barnes &#038; Noble.com
for marketing services, which includes the issuance of gift cards. Under this
agreement, the Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com $5.3&nbsp;million during fiscal 2002,
which represents reimbursement for gift cards purchased in a Barnes &#038; Noble
store and redeemed on the Barnes &#038; Noble.com Web site.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble.com, through its fulfillment centers, ships various
customer orders for the Company to its retail stores as well as to the
Company&#146;s customers&#146; homes. Barnes &#038; Noble.com charges the Company the costs
associated with such shipments plus any incremental overhead incurred by Barnes
&#038; Noble.com to process these orders. The Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com $1.7
million, $1.0&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million for shipping and handling during fiscal
years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. In addition, during fiscal 2001, the
Company and Barnes &#038; Noble.com reached an agreement whereby the Company pays a
commission on all items ordered by customers at the Company&#146;s stores and
shipped directly to customers&#146; homes by Barnes &#038; Noble.com. Commissions paid
for these sales were $1.5&nbsp;million and $0.4&nbsp;million during fiscal years 2002 and
2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company paid B&#038;N College certain operating costs B&#038;N College incurred
on the Company&#146;s behalf. These charges are included in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations and approximated $0.2&nbsp;million, $0.2
million and $0.3&nbsp;million for fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. B&#038;N
College purchased inventory, at cost plus an incremental fee, of $44.9&nbsp;million,
$41.5&nbsp;million and
$17.2&nbsp;million from the Company during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively. The Company charged B&#038;N College $2.1&nbsp;million, $1.5&nbsp;million and
$1.3&nbsp;million for fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively, for capital
expenditures, business insurance and other operating costs incurred on its
behalf.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-21</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses a jet aircraft owned by B&#038;N College and pays for the
costs and expenses of operating the aircraft based upon the Company&#146;s usage.
Such costs which include fuel, insurance, personnel and other costs,
approximated $1.9&nbsp;million, $2.2&nbsp;million and $2.4&nbsp;million during fiscal 2002,
2001 and 2000, respectively, and are included in the accompanying consolidated
statements of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Company acquired Babbage&#146;s Etc., one of the nation&#146;s
largest video-game and entertainment-software specialty retailers, a company
majority owned by Leonard Riggio, for $208.7&nbsp;million. An independent Special
Committee of the Board of Directors negotiated and approved the acquisition on
behalf of the Company. The Company made an additional payment of $9.7&nbsp;million
in fiscal 2002 due to certain financial performance targets having been met
during fiscal 2001. In fiscal 2000, the Company acquired Funco, Inc. Through a
corporate restructuring, Babbage&#146;s Etc. became a wholly owned subsidiary of
Funco, Inc. and the name of Funco, Inc. was changed to GameStop, Inc. In fiscal
2002, the Company completed an initial public offering of its GameStop
subsidiary. The Company retained an approximate 63&nbsp;percent interest in
GameStop.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop operates departments within some of the Company&#146;s bookstores.
GameStop pays a license fee to the Company in an amount equal to 7&nbsp;percent of
the gross sales of such departments. The Company charged GameStop a license fee
of $1.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop participates in the Company&#146;s worker&#146;s compensation, property and
general liability insurance programs. The costs incurred by the Company under
these programs are allocated to GameStop based upon GameStop&#146;s total payroll
expense, property and equipment, and insurance claim history. During fiscal
2002, these charges amounted to $1.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, Barnes &#038; Noble.com and GameStop entered into an agreement
whereby Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s Web site refers customers to the GameStop Web site
for purchases of video-game hardware, software and accessories and
PC-entertainment software. GameStop pays Barnes &#038; Noble.com a referral fee
based on its net sales revenue from certain eligible purchases made by
customers as a result of the redirection from the Barnes &#038; Noble.com Web site.
Either party may terminate the agreement on 60&nbsp;days&#146; notice. Commissions were
$0.0&nbsp;million and $0.1&nbsp;million for fiscal years 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is provided with national freight distribution, including
trucking, services by the LTA Group, Inc. (LTA), a company in which a brother
of Leonard Riggio owns a 20&nbsp;percent interest. The Company paid LTA $18.5
million, $17.7&nbsp;million and $16.7&nbsp;million for such services during fiscal years
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. The Company believes the cost of freight
delivered to the stores compares favorably to the prices charged by publishers
and other third-party freight distributors.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since 1993, the Company has used AEC One Stop Group, Inc. (AEC)&nbsp;as its
primary music and DVD/video supplier and to provide a music and video database.
AEC is one of the largest wholesale distributors of music and DVD/videos in
the United States. In 1999, AEC&#146;s parent corporation was acquired by an
investor group in which Leonard Riggio was a minority investor. The Company
paid AEC $246.4&nbsp;million, $169.9&nbsp;million and $160.8&nbsp;million for merchandise
purchased during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. In addition, the
Company paid AEC $7.7&nbsp;million, $2.6&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million for database
equipment and services during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
Amounts payable to
AEC for merchandise purchased were $22.0&nbsp;million and $51.1&nbsp;million as of
February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Newly Issued Accounting Pronouncements</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB)&nbsp;finalized
SFAS No.&nbsp;146 &#147;Accounting for the Costs Associated with Exit or Disposal
Activities&#148;, which requires the Company to
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-22</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">recognize costs associated with exit
or disposal activities when they are incurred rather than at the date of a
commitment to an exit or disposal plan. SFAS No.&nbsp;146 replaces Emerging Issues
Task Force (EITF)&nbsp;Issue No.&nbsp;94-3 &#147;Liability Recognition for Certain Employee
Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an Activity (Including Certain
Costs Incurred in a Restructuring)&#148;. The provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 are to be
applied prospectively to exit or disposal activities initiated after December
31, 2002. It is anticipated that the financial impact of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 will not
have a material effect on the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;148 &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation - Transition and Disclosure,&#148; which amends SFAS No.&nbsp;123
&#147;Stock-Based Compensation,&#148; to provide alternative methods of transition for a
voluntary change to the fair value-based method of accounting for stock-based
employee compensation. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amends the disclosure
requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosures in both annual
and interim financial statements about the method of accounting for stock-based
employee compensation and the effect of the method used on reported results.
The disclosure provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;148 are effective for fiscal years ending
after December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Company has incorporated these expanded
disclosures into the footnotes to the Company&#146;s financial statements included
herein.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the EITF reached a consensus on Issue 02-16 &#147;Accounting
by a Customer (Including a Reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a
Vendor&#148;, addressing the accounting of cash consideration received by a customer
from a vendor, including vendor rebates and refunds. The consensus reached
states that consideration received should be presumed to be a reduction of the
prices of the vendor&#146;s products or services and should therefore be shown as a
reduction of cost of sales in the income statement of the customer. The
presumption could be overcome if the vendor receives an identifiable benefit in
exchange for the consideration or the consideration represents a reimbursement
of a specific incremental identifiable cost incurred by the customer in selling
the vendor&#146;s product or service. If one of these conditions is met, the cash
consideration should be characterized as revenues or a reduction of such costs,
as applicable, in the income statement of the customer. The consensus reached
also concludes that rebates or refunds based on the customer achieving a
specified level of purchases should be recognized as a reduction of cost of
sales based on a systematic and rational allocation of the consideration to be
received relative to the transactions that mark the progress of the customer
toward earning the rebate or refund provided the amounts are probable and
reasonably estimable. EITF Issue 02-16 is effective for arrangements entered
into after December&nbsp;31, 2002. Implementation of this standard is not expected
to have a material effect on the Company&#146;s annual results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;45 &#147;Guarantor&#146;s
Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect
Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others&#148; (Interpretation 45). Interpretation 45
requires a guarantor to include disclosure of certain obligations, and if
applicable, at the inception of the guarantee, recognize a liability for the
fair value of other certain obligations undertaken in issuing a guarantee. The
recognition requirement is effective for guarantees issued or modified after
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and is not expected to have a material impact on the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2003, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;46 &#147;Consolidation of
Variable Interest
Entities&#148; (Interpretation 46). Interpretation 46 clarifies the
application of Accounting Research Bulletin No.&nbsp;51 &#147;Consolidated Financial
Statements&#148;, and applies immediately to any variable interest entities created
after January&nbsp;31, 2003 and to variable interest entities in which an interest
is obtained after that date. The Company holds no interest in variable
interest entities.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Disclosure Regarding Forward-Looking Statements</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This report may contain certain forward-looking statements (as such term
is defined in the Private
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-23</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995) and
information relating to the Company that are based on the beliefs of the
management of the Company as well as assumptions made by and information
currently available to the management of the Company. When used in this
report, the words &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148; &#147;estimate,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148; &#147;intend,&#148;
&#147;plan&#148; and similar expressions, as they relate to the Company or the management
of the Company, identify forward-looking statements. Such statements reflect
the current views of the Company with respect to future events, the outcome of
which is subject to certain risks, including among others general economic and
market conditions, decreased consumer demand for the Company&#146;s products,
possible disruptions in the Company&#146;s computer or telephone systems, possible
work stoppages or increases in labor costs, possible increases in shipping
rates or interruptions in shipping service, effects of competition, possible
disruptions or delays in the opening of new stores or the inability to obtain
suitable sites for new stores, higher-than-anticipated store closing or
relocation costs, higher interest rates, the performance of the Company&#146;s
online initiatives such as Barnes &#038; Noble.com, the performance and successful
integration of acquired businesses, the success of the Company&#146;s strategic
investments, unanticipated increases in merchandise or occupancy costs,
unanticipated adverse litigation results or effects, and other factors which
may be outside of the Company&#146;s control. In addition, the video-game market
has historically been cyclical in nature and dependent upon the introduction of
new generation systems and related interactive software. Should one or more of
these risks or uncertainties materialize, or should underlying assumptions
prove incorrect, actual results or outcomes may vary materially from those
described as anticipated, believed, estimated, expected, intended or planned.
Subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the
Company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their
entirety by the cautionary statements in this paragraph.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-28</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">(Thousands of dollars, except per
share data)<BR>
For the 52&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 (fiscal 2002), 52&nbsp;weeks ended February
2, 2002 (fiscal 2001) and 53&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;3, 2001 (fiscal 2000).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Business</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (Barnes &#038; Noble), through its subsidiaries
(collectively, the Company), is primarily engaged in the sale of books, video
games and entertainment-software products. The Company employs two principal
bookselling strategies: its superstore strategy through its wholly owned
subsidiary Barnes &#038; Noble Booksellers, Inc., under its Barnes &#038; Noble
Booksellers, Bookstop and Bookstar trade names (hereafter collectively referred
to as Barnes &#038; Noble stores) and its mall strategy through its wholly owned
subsidiaries B. Dalton Bookseller, Inc. and Doubleday Book Shops, Inc., under
its B. Dalton stores, Doubleday Book Shops and Scribner&#146;s Bookstore trade names
(hereafter collectively referred to as B. Dalton stores). The Company
publishes books under its own imprints which, since January 2003, also include
Sterling Publishing Co., Inc. and its various imprints. The Company is also
engaged in the online retailing of books and other products through an
approximate 38&nbsp;percent interest in barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes &#038; Noble.com),
as more fully described in Note 8. The Company, through its approximate 63
percent interest in GameStop Corp., operates video-game and
entertainment-software stores under the GameStop, Babbage&#146;s, Software Etc. and
FuncoLand trade names, a Web site (gamestop.com) and <I>Game Informer </I>magazine
(hereafter collectively referred to as GameStop stores). Additionally, the
Company owns an approximate 74&nbsp;percent interest in Calendar Club L.L.C.
(Calendar Club), an operator of seasonal calendar kiosks.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Consolidation</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Barnes &#038;
Noble and its wholly and majority-owned subsidiaries. Investments in
affiliates in which ownership interests range from 20&nbsp;percent to 50&nbsp;percent,
principally Barnes &#038; Noble.com, are accounted for under the equity method. All
significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in
consolidation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Use of Estimates</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In preparing financial statements in conformity with generally accepted
accounting principles, the Company is required to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the
disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial
statements and revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual
results could differ from those estimates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company considers all short-term, highly liquid instruments purchased
with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Merchandise Inventories</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merchandise inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market. Cost
is determined primarily by the retail inventory method on the first-in,
first-out (FIFO)&nbsp;basis for 82&nbsp;percent and 81&nbsp;percent of the Company&#146;s
merchandise inventories as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-29</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Merchandise inventories of GameStop stores and Calendar Club represent 12
percent and 11&nbsp;percent of merchandise inventories as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and
February&nbsp;2, 2002, respectively and are recorded
based on the average cost method. The remaining merchandise inventories are
valued on the last-in, first-out (LIFO)&nbsp;method.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If substantially all of the merchandise inventories currently valued at
LIFO costs were valued at current costs, merchandise inventories would remain
unchanged as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Property and Equipment</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are carried at cost, less accumulated depreciation
and amortization. For financial reporting purposes, depreciation is computed
using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives. For tax purposes,
different methods are used. Maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred,
while betterments and major remodeling costs are capitalized. Leasehold
improvements are capitalized and amortized over the shorter of their estimated
useful lives or the terms of the respective leases. Capitalized lease
acquisition costs are being amortized over the lease terms of the underlying
leases. Costs incurred in purchasing management information systems are
capitalized and included in property and equipment. These costs are amortized
over their estimated useful lives from the date the systems become operational.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Goodwill</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The costs in excess of net assets of businesses acquired are carried as
goodwill in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB)&nbsp;finalized
Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;141, &#147;Business
Combinations"<I>, </I>and SFAS No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148;. SFAS
No.&nbsp;141 requires business combinations initiated after June&nbsp;30, 2001 to be
accounted for using the purchase method of accounting, and broadens the
criteria for recording intangible assets apart from goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142
requires that purchased goodwill and certain indefinite-lived intangibles no
longer be amortized, but instead be tested for impairment at least annually.
As a result of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;142, the Company ceased amortization of
goodwill beginning February&nbsp;3, 2002. Prior to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142,
the Company amortized goodwill on a straight-line basis over 30 to 40&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;142 prescribes a two-step process for impairment testing of
goodwill. The first step of this test, used to identify potential
impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying
amount, including goodwill. The second step (if necessary) measures the
amount of the impairment. Using the guidance in SFAS No.&nbsp;142, the Company
has determined that it has two reporting units, bookstores and video-game and
entertainment-software stores. The Company completed its initial impairment
test on the goodwill in the second quarter of fiscal 2002 and its annual
impairment test in November 2002. Both tests indicated that the fair value
of the reporting units exceeded that reporting unit&#146;s carrying amount;
accordingly, the second testing phase was not necessary. The Company has
noted no subsequent indicators that would require testing goodwill for
impairment.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-30</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s long-lived assets include property and equipment and
goodwill. At February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company had $622,303 of property and
equipment, net of accumulated depreciation, and $438,572 of goodwill, net of
amortization, accounting for approximately 35.4% of the Company&#146;s total assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company periodically reviews its property and equipment under SFAS No.
144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets,&#148; whenever
events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amounts may not
be recoverable or their depreciation periods should be accelerated. Factors
that the Company considers important which could trigger a review include the
following:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant changes in the manner of use of the assets</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant changes in the strategy of the overall business</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Significant underperformance relative to expected historical
or projected future operating results</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Recoverability is assessed based on several factors, including
management&#146;s intentions with respect to its stores and those stores&#146; projected
undiscounted cash flows. Assumptions underlying such projected cash flows
include historical experience of stores, competitive environment, purchasing
trends and projected demographics in the areas.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If it is determined that the carrying value of long-lived assets may not
be recoverable, the Company measures impairment based on the present values of
the projected cash flows using a discount rate determined by the Company&#146;s
management to be commensurate with the risk involved.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-31</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Deferred Charges</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs incurred to obtain long-term financing are amortized over the terms
of the respective debt agreements using the straight-line method, which
approximates the interest method. Unamortized costs included in other
noncurrent assets as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002 were $11,130 and
$10,436, respectively. Amortization expense included in interest and
amortization of deferred financing fees were $2,894, $2,292 and $1,557 during
fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Derivative Instruments</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under an agreement which expired February&nbsp;3, 2003, the Company used an
interest-rate swap as a derivative to modify the interest characteristics of
its outstanding floating rate debt, thereby reducing its exposure to
fluctuations in interest rates. The Company&#146;s accounting policy was based on
its designation of such instruments as cash flow hedges whereby changes in the
fair value in the derivative have been included in other comprehensive income.
The Company did not enter into the contract for speculative purposes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Revenue Recognition</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from sales of the Company&#146;s products is recognized at the time of
sale. Sales returns (which are not significant) are recognized at the time
returns are made.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Readers&#146; Advantage&#153; membership entitles the customer to receive a 10
percent discount on all purchases made during the twelve-month membership
period. The annual membership fee of $25.00 is non-refundable after the first
30&nbsp;days of the membership term. Revenue is being recognized over the
twelve-month membership period based upon historical spending patterns for
Barnes &#038; Noble customers. Refunds of membership fees due to cancellations
within the first 30&nbsp;days are minimal.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subscription revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis as magazine
issues are delivered.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Advertising Costs</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The costs of advertising are expensed as incurred during the year pursuant
to Statement of Position 93-7, &#147;Reporting on Advertising Costs&#148;. In addition,
consideration received from vendors in conjunction with the Company&#146;s
cooperative advertising program is netted against the related expenses.
Advertising costs are charged to selling and administrative expenses. As a
result of new requirements set forth in Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF)&nbsp;Issue
02-16 &#147;Accounting by a Customer (Including a Reseller) for Certain
Consideration Received from a Vendor&#148;, which are effective for arrangements
entered into after December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company may be required to reclassify
some of its co-op advertising from an offset to selling and administrative
expenses to a reduction in costs of sales and occupancy. The Company does not
expect implementation of EITF Issue 02-16 to have a material effect on its
annual results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Closed Store Expenses</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon a formal decision to close or relocate a store, the Company charges
unrecoverable costs to expense. Such costs include the net book value of
abandoned fixtures and leasehold improvements and, when a store is closed, a
provision for future lease obligations, net of expected sublease recoveries.
Costs associated with store closings of $10,111, $9,831 and $5,026 during
fiscal 2002, fiscal 2001 and fiscal
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-32</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">2000, respectively, are included in selling and administrative expenses in the
accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Net Earnings Per Common Share</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to
common shareholders by the weighted-average number of common shares
outstanding. Diluted earnings per share reflect, in periods in which they have
a dilutive effect, the impact of common shares issuable upon exercise of its
stock options and those of its GameStop subsidiary, and assumes the conversion
of the Company&#146;s 5.25% convertible subordinated notes for the period
outstanding since their issuance in March 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The provision for income taxes includes federal, state and local income
taxes currently payable and those deferred because of temporary differences
between the financial statement and tax bases of assets and liabilities. The
deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the enacted tax rates
and laws that are expected to be in effect when the differences reverse.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Stock Options</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company grants options to purchase Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (BKS)&nbsp;and
GameStop Corp. (GME)&nbsp;common shares under stock-based incentive plans, which are
described more fully in Note 17. The Company accounts for all transactions
under which employees receive shares of stock or other equity instruments in
the Company or the Company incurs liabilities to employees in amounts based on
the price of its stock in accordance with the provisions of Accounting
Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&#148;.
The following table illustrates the effect on net income and earnings per share
as if the Company had applied the fair value-recognition provisions of SFAS No.
123, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation&#148;, to stock-based incentive plans:
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-33</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Reclassifications</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain prior-period amounts have been reclassified for comparative
purposes to conform with the fiscal 2002 presentation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Reporting Period</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s fiscal year is comprised of 52 or 53&nbsp;weeks, ending on the
Saturday closest to the last day of January. The reporting periods ended
February&nbsp;1, 2003, February&nbsp;2, 2002 and February&nbsp;3, 2001 contained 52&nbsp;weeks, 52
weeks and 53&nbsp;weeks, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Newly Issued Accounting Pronouncements</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, the FASB finalized SFAS No.&nbsp;146 &#147;Accounting for the Costs
Associated with Exit or Disposal Activities&#148;, which requires the Company to
recognize costs associated with exit or disposal activities when they are
incurred rather than at the date of a commitment to an exit or disposal plan.
SFAS No.&nbsp;146 replaces EITF Issue No.&nbsp;94-3 &#147;Liability Recognition for Certain
Employee Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an Activity (Including
Certain Costs Incurred in a Restructuring)&#148;. The provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146
are to be applied prospectively to exit or disposal activities initiated after
December&nbsp;31, 2002. It is anticipated that the financial impact of SFAS No.&nbsp;146
will not have a material effect on the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;148 &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation - Transition and Disclosure,&#148; which amends SFAS No.&nbsp;123
&#147;Stock-Based Compensation,&#148; to provide alternative methods of transition for a
voluntary change to the fair value based method of accounting for stock-based
employee compensation. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amends the disclosure
requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosures in both annual
and interim financial statements about the method of accounting for stock-based
employee compensation and the effect of the method used on reported results.
The disclosure provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;148 are effective for fiscal years ending
after December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Company has incorporated the expanded disclosures
into these footnotes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the EITF reached a consensus on Issue 02-16 &#147;Accounting
by a Customer (Including a Reseller) for Certain Consideration Received from a
Vendor&#148;, addressing the accounting of cash consideration received by a customer
from a vendor, including vendor rebates and refunds. The consensus reached
states that consideration received should be presumed to be a reduction of the
prices of the vendor&#146;s products or services and should therefore be shown as a
reduction of cost of sales in the income statement of the customer. The
presumption could be overcome if the vendor receives an identifiable benefit in
exchange for the consideration or the consideration represents a reimbursement
of a specific incremental identifiable cost incurred by the customer in selling
the vendor&#146;s product or service. If one of these conditions is met, the cash
consideration should be characterized as revenues or a reduction of such costs,
as applicable, in the income statement of the customer. The consensus reached
also concludes that rebates or refunds based on the customer achieving a
specified level of purchases should be recognized as a reduction of cost of
sales based on a systematic and rational allocation of the consideration to be
received relative to the transactions that mark the progress of the customer
toward earning the rebate or refund provided the amounts are probable and
reasonably estimable. EITF Issue 02-16 is effective for arrangements entered
into after December&nbsp;31, 2002. Implementation of this standard is not expected
to have a material effect on the Company&#146;s annual results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;45 &#147;Guarantor&#146;s
Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect
Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others&#148; (Interpretation 45). Interpretation 45
requires a guarantor to include disclosure of certain obligations,
and</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-34</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">if applicable, at the inception of the guarantee, recognize a liability
for the fair value of other certain obligations undertaken in issuing a
guarantee. The recognition requirement is effective for guarantees issued or
modified after December&nbsp;31, 2002 and is not expected to have a material impact
on the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2003, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;46 &#147;Consolidation of
Variable Interest Entities&#148; (Interpretation 46). Interpretation 46 clarifies
the application of Accounting Research Bulletin No.&nbsp;51 &#147;Consolidated Financial
Statements&#148;, and applies immediately to any variable interest entities created
after January&nbsp;31, 2003 and to variable interest entities in which an interest
is obtained after that date. The Company holds no interest in variable
interest entities.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>2. Receivables, Net</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Receivables represent customer, credit card, landlord and other
receivables due within one year as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="65%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Credit card receivables consist of receivables from credit card
companies. The Company assumes no customer credit risk for these
receivables.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>3. Debt</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;22, 2002, the Company obtained a $500,000 three-year senior
revolving credit facility (the Facility) with a syndicate of banks led by Fleet
National Bank as administrative agent. The Facility, which expires in May
2005, replaced the Company&#146;s $850,000 five-year senior revolving credit
facility obtained on November&nbsp;18, 1997. The Facility permits borrowings at
various interest-rate options based on the prime rate or London Interbank Offer
Rate (LIBOR)&nbsp;plus applicable margin depending upon the level of the Company&#146;s
fixed charge coverage ratio. The Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage is calculated
as the ratio of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and
rents to interest plus rents. In addition, the Facility requires the Company to
pay a commitment fee of 0.25&nbsp;percent, which fee varies based upon the Company&#146;s
fixed charge coverage ratio, calculated as a percentage of the unused portion.
The Company is required to pay utilization fees of 0.125&nbsp;percent or 0.25
percent on all outstanding loans under the Facility if the aggregate
outstanding loans are greater than 33&nbsp;percent and 66&nbsp;percent, respectively, of
the aggregate amount of the Facility.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A portion of the Facility, not to exceed $100,000, is available for the
issuance of letters of credit. Also, under certain circumstances, the Company
may be permitted to increase the size of the Facility to an amount not to
exceed $600,000 and/or to extend the term of the Facility by one additional
year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mandatory prepayments include the requirement that loans outstanding under
the Facility be reduced by 100&nbsp;percent of the net cash proceeds from (i)&nbsp;the
disposition of the Company&#146;s stock in certain entities, (ii)&nbsp;any equity
issuance, and (iii)&nbsp;the disposition of certain other material assets, other
than those assets disposed of during the ordinary course of business. Under
certain circumstances, mandatory
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-35</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">commitment reductions may include the requirement that the aggregate size of
the Facility be reduced upon the disposition by the Company of its stock in
GameStop.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Facility contains covenants, limitations and events of default typical
of credit facilities of this size and nature, including financial covenants,
which require the Company to meet, among other things, leverage and fixed
charge coverage ratios and which limit capital expenditures. Negative covenants
include limitations on other indebtedness, liens, investments, mergers,
consolidations, sales or leases of assets, acquisitions, distributions and
dividends and other payments in respect of capital stock, transactions with
affiliates, and sale/leaseback transactions. In the event the Company defaults
on these financial covenants, all outstanding borrowings under the Facility may
become immediately payable and no further borrowings may be available. The
Facility is secured by the Company&#146;s capital stock in its subsidiaries, and by
the accounts receivable and certain general intangibles of the Company and its
subsidiaries. Net proceeds from the Facility are available for general
corporate purposes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company issued $300,000, 5.25&nbsp;percent convertible
subordinated notes due March&nbsp;15, 2009. The notes are convertible into the
Company&#146;s common stock at a conversion price of $32.512 per share.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2000, the Company obtained an additional $100,000 senior
unsecured seasonal credit facility (seasonal credit facility) with a syndicate
of banks led by The Chase Manhattan Bank. The seasonal credit facility, which
matured on January&nbsp;31, 2001, permitted for borrowings at an interest rate based
on LIBOR. In addition, the agreement required the Company to pay a commitment
fee of 0.375&nbsp;percent of the unused portion. The seasonal credit facility was
guaranteed by all restricted subsidiaries of Barnes &#038; Noble.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company from time to time enters into interest rate swap agreements to
manage interest-costs and risk associated with changes in interest rates. These
agreements effectively convert underlying variable-rate debt based on prime
rate or LIBOR to fixed-rate debt through the exchange of fixed and floating
interest payment obligations without the exchange of underlying principal
amounts. For each of the years ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002, the
Company had a notional amount outstanding of $55,000 in swaps, maturing on
February&nbsp;3, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selected information related to the Company&#146;s convertible subordinated
notes, revolving credit facility and seasonal credit facility is as follows:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fees expensed with respect to the unused portion of the Company&#146;s

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The amounts outstanding under the Company&#146;s revolving credit facility have
been classified as long-term debt based on the Company&#146;s intention and ability
to maintain principal amounts outstanding.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has no agreements to maintain compensating balances.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-36</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>4. Fair Values of Financial Instruments</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents reported in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets approximate fair value due to the
short-term maturities of these assets. The aggregate fair value of the
Revolving Credit Facility approximates its carrying amount, because of its
recent and frequent repricing based upon market conditions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest-rate swap agreements are valued based on market quotes obtained
from dealers. The estimated fair value of the interest-rate swaps liability was
$6 and $2,256 at February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002, respectively. The
interest-rate swaps are included as a component of other long-term liabilities.
</FONT>

    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(9,346</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>

investment is being accounted for under the equity method.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

its investment occurred which is other than temporary. This resulted in
the recognition of losses in excess of what would otherwise be recognized
by application of the equity method in accordance with Accounting
Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;18, &#147;The Equity Method of Accounting for
Investments in Common Stock.&#148; The investment balance is $0 at February&nbsp;1,
2003.</FONT></TD>

Noble, Inc.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>8. Barnes &#038; Noble.com</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;12, 1998, the Company and Bertelsmann AG (Bertelsmann)
completed the formation of a limited liability company to operate the online
retail bookselling operations of the Company&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary,
barnesandnoble.com inc. The new entity, barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes &#038;
Noble.com), was structured as a limited liability company. Under the terms of
the relevant agreements, effective as of October&nbsp;31, 1998, the Company and
Bertelsmann each retained a 50&nbsp;percent membership interest in Barnes &#038;
Noble.com. The Company contributed substantially all of the assets and
liabilities of its online operations to the joint venture and Bertelsmann paid
$75,000 to the Company and made a $150,000 cash contribution to the joint
venture. Bertelsmann also agreed to contribute an additional $50,000 to the
joint venture for future working capital requirements. The Company recognized a
pre-tax gain during fiscal 1998 in the amount of $126,435, of which $63,759 was
recognized in earnings based on the $75,000 received directly and $62,676
($36,351 after taxes) was reflected in additional paid-in capital based on the
Company&#146;s share of the incremental equity of the joint venture resulting from
the $150,000 Bertelsmann contribution.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;25, 1999, Barnes &#038; Noble.com Inc. completed an IPO of 28.75&nbsp;million
shares of Class&nbsp;A Common Stock and used the proceeds to purchase a 20&nbsp;percent
interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. As a result, the Company and Bertelsmann each
retained a 40&nbsp;percent interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com.
The</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-39</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Company recorded an increase in additional paid-in capital of $116,158
after taxes representing the Company&#146;s incremental share in the equity of
Barnes &#038; Noble.com. In November 2000, Barnes &#038; Noble.com acquired
Fatbrain.com, Inc. (Fatbrain), the third largest online bookseller. Barnes &#038;
Noble.com issued shares of its common stock to Fatbrain shareholders. As a
result of this merger, the Company and Bertelsmann each retained an approximate
36&nbsp;percent interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. In October 2002, the Company
announced its intent to purchase up to $10,000 of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A
Common Stock in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions.
As of February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company purchased approximately 1.7&nbsp;million shares
of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A Common Stock. Subsequent to the fiscal 2002&nbsp;year
end, the Company purchased additional shares and currently has a 38&nbsp;percent
interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The Company will continue to account for its
investment under the equity method.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the terms of the November&nbsp;12, 1998 joint venture agreement between
the Company and Bertelsmann, the Company received a $25,000 payment from
Bertelsmann in connection with the IPO. The Company recognized the $25,000
pre-tax gain in fiscal 1999. The estimated fair market values of the Company&#146;s
investment in Barnes &#038; Noble.com were $60,386, $109,825 and $122,000 at
February&nbsp;1, 2003, February&nbsp;2, 2002 and February&nbsp;3, 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summarized financial information for Barnes &#038; Noble.com follows:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>9. Employees&#146; Retirement and Defined Contribution Plans</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 1999, substantially all employees of the Company were
covered under a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan (the Pension
Plan). As of January&nbsp;1, 2000, the Pension Plan was amended so that employees
no longer earn benefits for subsequent service. Subsequent service continues
to be the basis for vesting of benefits not yet vested at December&nbsp;31, 1999 and
the Pension Plan will continue to hold assets and pay benefits. The amendment
was treated as a curtailment in fiscal 1999 resulting in a pre-tax gain of
$14,142 which is included as a reduction of selling and administrative
expenses.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains defined contribution plans (the Savings Plans) for
the benefit of substantially all employees. In addition, the Company provides
certain health care and life insurance benefits (the Postretirement Plan) to
retired employees, limited to those receiving benefits or retired as of April
1, 1993.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-40</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A summary of the components of net periodic cost for the Pension Plan and
the Postretirement Plan follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total Company contributions charged to employee benefit expenses for the
Savings Plans were $6,709, $5,929 and $5,681 during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-41</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Settlements in the form of lump sum cash payments were made in fiscal 2001
to plan participants in exchange for their rights to receive specified pension
benefits.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The health-care cost trend rate used to measure the expected cost of the
Postretirement Plan benefits is assumed to be nine percent in 2002 declining at
one percent decrements each year through 2005 and one-half percent decrements
through 2007 to five percent in 2007 and each year thereafter. The health-care
cost trend assumption has a significant effect on the amounts reported. For
example, a one percent increase or decrease in the health-care cost trend rate
would change the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation by approximately
$328 and $291, respectively, as of February&nbsp;1, 2003, and would change the net
periodic cost by approximately $22 and $19, respectively, during fiscal 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-42</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
