<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-44</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>11. Acquisitions</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;21, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of Sterling
Publishing, one of the top 25 publishers in the nation and the industry&#146;s
leading publisher of how-to books, for $122,593 including $7,415 paid to reduce
short-term debt. The acquisition was accounted for by the purchase method of
accounting and, accordingly, the results of operations for the period
subsequent to the acquisition are included in the consolidated financial
statements. The excess of purchase price over the net assets acquired of
approximately $45,000 has been recorded as goodwill and will be tested annually
for impairment in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;142. The Company has engaged a firm
to perform an independent allocation of purchased intangibles between finite-
and indefinite-lived assets. Assets determined to have a finite life will be
amortized over their useful lives. The impact of amortization expense on the
Company&#146;s annual earnings is not expected to be material. The pro forma effect
assuming the acquisition of Sterling Publishing at the beginning of fiscal 2001
is not material.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>12. GameStop Initial Public Offering</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Company acquired Babbage&#146;s Etc., one of the nation&#146;s
largest video-game and entertainment-software specialty retailers, a company
majority owned by Leonard Riggio, for $208,670. An independent Special
Committee of the Board of Directors negotiated and approved the acquisition on
behalf of the Company. The Company made an additional payment of $9,665 in
2002 due to certain financial performance targets having been met during fiscal
year 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;14, 2000, the Company acquired all of the outstanding shares of
Funco, Inc., a Minneapolis-based electronic games retailer for approximately
$167,560. The acquisition was accounted for by the purchase method of
accounting and, accordingly, the results of operations for the period
subsequent to the acquisition are included in the consolidated financial
statements. The excess of purchase price over the net assets acquired, in the
amount of approximately $131,400, has been recorded as goodwill and is tested
for impairment at least annually, in conformity with SFAS No.&nbsp;142.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through a corporate restructuring, Babbage&#146;s Etc. became a wholly owned
subsidiary of Funco, Inc. and the name of Funco, Inc. was changed to GameStop,
Inc.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2002, GameStop completed an initial public offering of shares
of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at a price of $18.00 per share, raising net
proceeds of approximately $348,000. A portion of the net proceeds was used to
repay $250,000 of indebtedness to the Company, with the Company contributing
the remaining $150,000 of indebtedness to GameStop as additional paid-in
capital. The balance of the net proceeds (approximately $98,000) is being used
for working capital and general corporate purposes for GameStop. The Company
owns approximately 63&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of GameStop&#146;s capital
stock through its ownership of 100&nbsp;percent of GameStop&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common stock,
which represents 94.5&nbsp;percent of the combined voting power of all classes of
GameStop voting stock. The Company recorded an increase in additional paid-in
capital of $155,490 ($90,184 after taxes), representing the Company&#146;s
incremental share in the equity of GameStop.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-45</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>13. Segment Information</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates under two strategic groups that offer different
products. These groups have been aggregated into two reportable operating
segments: bookstores and video-game and entertainment-software stores.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Bookstores</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This segment includes 628 bookstores under the Barnes &#038; Noble Booksellers,
Bookstop and Bookstar names which generally offer a comprehensive title base, a
caf&#233;, a children&#146;s section, a music department, a magazine section and a
calendar of ongoing events, including author appearances and children&#146;s
activities. This segment also includes 258 small format mall-based stores
under the B. Dalton Bookseller, Doubleday Book Shops and Scribner&#146;s Bookstore
trade names. The Company&#146;s publishing operation is also included in this
segment. Additionally, this segment includes the operations of Calendar Club,
the Company&#146;s majority-owned subsidiary. Calendar Club is an operator of
seasonal calendar kiosks. The bookstore segment employs a merchandising
strategy that targets the mainstream consumer book market.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Video-Game and Entertainment-Software Stores</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This segment includes 1,231 Video Game &#038; Entertainment Software stores
under the Babbage&#146;s, Software Etc., GameStop and FuncoLand names, a Web site
(gamestop.com) and <I>Game Informer </I>magazine. The principal products of these
stores are comprised of video-game hardware and software and PC-entertainment
software. The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements reflect the results
of Babbage&#146;s Etc. from October 1999 and Funco, Inc. from June 2000, the
respective dates of acquisition.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accounting policies of the segments are the same as those described in
the summary of significant accounting policies. Segment operating profit
includes corporate expenses in each operating segment. Barnes &#038; Noble
evaluates the performance of its segments and allocates resources to them based
on operating profit.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summarized financial information concerning the Company&#146;s reportable
segments is presented below:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="95%">

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>14. Comprehensive Earnings (Loss)</B></FONT>

recorded directly to shareholders&#146; equity. The only such items currently
applicable to the Company are the unrealized losses on available-for-sale
securities and derivative instruments, as follows:

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>15. Shareholders&#146; Equity</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Board of Directors authorized a common stock
repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250,000 of the Company&#146;s common
shares. As of February&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company has repurchased 8,502,700 shares at
a cost of approximately $181,391 under this program. The repurchased shares
are held in treasury.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each share of the Company&#146;s Common Stock also entitles the holder to the
right (the Right) to purchase one four-hundredth of a share of the Company&#146;s
Series&nbsp;H Preferred Stock for $225. The Right is only exercisable if a person
or group acquires 15&nbsp;percent or more of the Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock
or announces a tender offer or exchange offer, the consummation of which would
result in such person or group owning 15&nbsp;percent or more of the Company&#146;s
outstanding Common Stock.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>16. Impairment Charge</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company deemed the decline in
value in its available-for-sale securities in Gemstar-TV Guide International,
Inc. (Gemstar) and Indigo Books &#038; Music Inc. (Indigo) to be other than
temporary. The investments had been carried at fair market value with
unrealized gains and losses included in shareholders&#146; equity. Events such as
Gemstar&#146;s largest shareholder taking an impairment charge for its investment,
the precipitous decline in the stock price subsequent to the abrupt resignation
of one of its senior executives, the questioning of aggressive revenue
recognition policies and the filing of a class action lawsuit against Gemstar,
were among the items which led to management&#146;s decision to record an impairment
for its investment in Gemstar of nearly $24,000 (before taxes). The
Company&#146;s decision to record an impairment charge for its investment in
Indigo was based on a review of Indigo&#146;s financial condition and historical
share trading data. As a result, the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-48</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Company recorded a non-cash impairment
charge to operating earnings of $25,328 ($14,944 after taxes) to reclassify the
accumulated unrealized losses and to write down the investments to their
current fair market value at the close of business on May&nbsp;4, 2002. In the
second quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company sold its investment in Gemstar
resulting in a loss of $297.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal 2000, the Company recorded a non-cash charge to operating
earnings of $106,833. This charge included approximately $69,928 of goodwill
and $32,405 of property, plant and equipment related to the book business,
primarily goodwill associated with the purchase of B. Dalton, other
mall-bookstore assets and $6,186 of warehouse equipment. The Company&#146;s
small-format mall-based bookstores have experienced significant declines in
sales and profitability as a result of increased competition from book
superstores and Internet book retailers. In fiscal 2000, B. Dalton comparable
store sales declined (1.7%) compared with an increase in comparable store sales
of 0.1% in fiscal 1999. As a result, the anticipated future cash flows from
certain stores were no longer sufficient to recover the carrying value of the
underlying assets. Also, included in this charge were other charges of $4,500
related to the write-off of certain investments which had continuing adverse
financial results. The estimated fair value of the assets was based on
anticipated future cash flows discounted at a rate commensurate with the risk
involved.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>17. Stock Option Plans</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company grants options to purchase Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (BKS)&nbsp;and
GameStop Corp. (GME)&nbsp;common shares under the incentive plans discussed below.
In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;123, the Company discloses the pro forma impact of
recording compensation expense utilizing the Black-Scholes model. The
Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the
fair value of traded options which have no vesting restrictions and are fully
transferable. In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly
subjective assumptions including the expected stock price volatility. Because
the stock options have characteristics significantly different from those of
traded options, and because changes in the subjective input assumptions can
materially affect the fair value estimate, in management&#146;s opinion, the
Black-Scholes model does not necessarily provide a reliable measure of the fair
value of the companies&#146; stock options. The pro forma effect on net income and
earnings per share, had the Company applied the fair-value-recognition
provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, is shown in Note 1.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>BKS Stock Option Plans</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has two incentive plans under which stock options
have been or may be granted to officers, directors and key employees of the
Company, the 1991 Employee Incentive Plan (the 1991 Plan) and the 1996
Incentive Plan (the 1996 Plan). The options to purchase common shares generally
are issued at fair market value on the date of the grant, begin vesting after
one year in 33-1/3&nbsp;percent or 25&nbsp;percent increments per year, expire 10&nbsp;years
from issuance and are conditioned upon continual employment during the vesting
period.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 1996 Plan and the 1991 Plan allow the Company to grant options to
purchase up to 14,500,000 and 4,732,704 shares of common stock, respectively.
No more grants may be made under the 1991 Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the two incentive plans, the Company has granted stock
options to certain key executives and directors. The vesting terms and
contractual lives of these grants are similar to that of the
incentive plans.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-49</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;24, 2002, Leonard Riggio, the Company&#146;s Chairman, entered into an
Agreement with Stephen Riggio, the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer, which was
approved by the Compensation Committee of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors. The
Agreement granted Stephen Riggio options to direct Leonard Riggio to exercise
certain stock options held by Leonard Riggio covering 2,000,000 shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock. Upon any such exercise, Stephen Riggio would be
entitled to the value of the underlying common stock to the extent it exceeds
certain specified values, none of which is less than the quoted market price of
the stock at the date of the Agreement. The Agreement was entered into in
connection with Stephen Riggio&#146;s succeeding Leonard Riggio as the Company&#146;s
Chief Executive Officer. The options have been accounted for under APB 25.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted-average fair value of the options granted during fiscal 2002,
2001 and 2000 were estimated at $8.96, $10.13 and $7.86, respectively, using
the Black-Scholes option-pricing model with the following assumptions:

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>GME Stock Option Plans</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August 2001, the Company approved the 2001 Incentive Plan of GameStop
Corp. (the 2001 Plan). The 2001 Plan assumed (by the issuance of replacement
options) all stock options outstanding as of the effective date under the 2000
Incentive Plan of GameStop, Inc. (the 2000 Plan) under the same terms.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;13, 2000, the Company approved the 2000 Plan. The
2000 Plan provides a maximum aggregate amount of 15,000,000 shares of common
stock with respect to which options may be granted and provides for the
granting of incentive stock options, non-qualified stock options, and
restricted stock, which may include, without limitation, restrictions on the
right to vote such shares and restrictions on the right to receive dividends on
such shares. The options to purchase common shares generally are issued at fair
market value on the date of grant. Generally, the options vest and become
exercisable ratably over a three-year period, commencing one year after the
grant date, and expire ten years from issuance.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-51</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases retail stores, warehouse facilities, office space and
equipment. Substantially all of the retail stores are leased under
noncancelable agreements which expire at various dates through 2036 with
various renewal options for additional periods. The agreements, which have been
classified as operating leases, generally provide for both minimum and
percentage rentals and require the Company to pay all insurance, taxes and
other maintenance costs. Percentage rentals are based on sales performance in
excess of specified minimums at various stores.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rental expense under operating leases are as follows:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases one of its distribution facilities located in South
Brunswick, New Jersey from the New Jersey Economic Development Authority
(NJEDA)&nbsp;under the terms of an operating lease expiring in June 2011. Under the
terms of this lease, the Company provides a residual value guarantee to the
NJEDA, in an amount not to exceed $5,000, relating to the fair market value of
this distribution facility calculated at the conclusion of the lease term. The
Company believes that the possibility that any such payment would be required
under this guarantee is remote.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Legal Proceedings</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August 1998, The Intimate Bookshop, Inc. and its owner, Wallace Kuralt,
filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District
of New York against the Company, Borders Group, Inc. and others, alleging
violation of the Robinson-Patman Act and other federal law, New York statutes
governing trade practices and common law. In March 2000, a Second Amended
Complaint was served on the Company and other defendants alleging a single
cause of action for violations of the Robinson-Patman
Act. The Second Amended Complaint claims that The Intimate Bookshop, Inc.
has suffered damages of $11,250 or more and requests treble damages, costs,
attorneys&#146; fees and interest, as well as
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-53</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">declaratory and injunctive relief
prohibiting the defendants from violating the Robinson-Patman Act. The Company
served an Answer in April 2000 denying the material allegations of the Second
Amended Complaint and asserting various affirmative defenses. On January&nbsp;11,
2002, the Company and the other defendants filed a motion for summary judgment.
A hearing on that motion was held on March&nbsp;22, 2002. The Company intends to
vigorously defend this action.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;14, 2003, a Company employee filed a class action lawsuit against
the Company in the Superior Court of California for the County of Orange (Case
No.&nbsp;03CC00088). The complaint alleges that the Company improperly classified
the assistant store managers, department managers and receiving managers
working in its California stores as salaried exempt employees. The complaint
alleges that these employees spent more than 50&nbsp;percent of their time
performing non-exempt work and should have been classified as non-exempt
employees. The complaint alleges violations of the California Labor Code and
California Business and Professions Code and seeks relief, including unpaid
overtime compensation, prejudgment interest, penalties, attorneys&#146; fees and
costs. The Company intends to vigorously defend this action, including
contesting its certification as a class action.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the above actions, various claims and lawsuits arising in
the normal course of business are pending against the Company. The subject
matter of these proceedings primarily includes commercial disputes, personal
injury claims and employment issues. The results of these proceedings are not
expected to have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated
financial position or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain Relationships and Related Transactions</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company believes that the transactions and agreements discussed below
(including renewals of any existing agreements) between the Company and its
affiliates are at least as favorable to the Company as could be obtained from
unaffiliated parties. The Board of Directors and the Audit Committee are
designated to approve in advance any new proposed transaction or agreement with
affiliates and will utilize procedures in evaluating the terms and provisions
of such proposed transaction or agreement as are appropriate in light of the
fiduciary duties of directors under Delaware law.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases space for its executive offices in properties in which
Leonard Riggio has a minority interest. The space was rented at an aggregate
annual rent including real estate taxes of approximately $4,043, $3,966 and
$3,378 in fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Rent per square foot
is approximately $28.00, which is below market.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases a 75,000-square-foot office/warehouse from a
partnership in which Leonard Riggio has a 50&nbsp;percent interest, pursuant to a
lease expiring in 2023. Pursuant to such lease, the Company paid $752, $490
and $648 in fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases retail space in a building in which Barnes &#038; Noble
College Bookstores, Inc. (B&#038;N College), a company owned by Leonard Riggio,
subleases space for its executive offices from the Company. Occupancy costs
allocated by the Company to B&#038;N College for this space totaled $771, $748 and
$709 for fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. The amount paid by
B&#038;N College to the
Company approximates the cost per square foot paid by the Company to its
unaffiliated third-party landlord.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company subleased warehouse space from Barnes &#038; Noble.com in Reno,
Nevada. The Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com $279, $1,838 and $1,401 for such
subleased space during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Additionally,
in January 2001, the Company purchased $6,186 of warehouse equipment (valued at
original cost) from Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s Reno warehouse. In January
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-54</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">2002,
Barnes &#038; Noble.com determined it could not effectively utilize the full
capacity of the Reno, Nevada distribution center. As a result, Barnes &#038;
Noble.com&#146;s Board of Directors approved the transfer of the Reno warehouse
lease and the sale of inventory located in Reno to the Company. The Company
purchased the inventory from Barnes &#038; Noble.com at cost for $9,877. In
addition, the Company spent $1,755 to refurbish the facility. The Company&#146;s
Board of Directors also approved the Company&#146;s assumption of the lease, which
expires in 2010, and the hiring of all of the employees at the Reno facility.
The Reno lease assignment and the transfer of the Reno facility to the Company
was completed in April 2002. The Company intends to use the Reno facility to
facilitate distribution to its current and future West Coast stores. In
connection with the transition, Barnes &#038; Noble.com agreed to pay one-half of
the rent for the Reno facility through December&nbsp;31, 2002. Barnes &#038; Noble.com
paid $905 in relation to these expenses for fiscal year 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company subleases to Barnes &#038; Noble.com approximately one-third of a
300,000-square-foot warehouse facility located in New Jersey. The Company has
received from Barnes &#038; Noble.com $498, $479 and $489 for such subleased space
during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. The amount paid by Barnes &#038;
Noble.com to the Company approximates the cost per square foot paid by the
Company as a tenant pursuant to the lease of the space from an unaffiliated
third party.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has entered into an agreement (the Supply Agreement) with
Barnes &#038; Noble.com whereby the Company charges Barnes &#038; Noble.com the costs
associated with such purchases plus incremental overhead incurred by the
Company in connection with providing such inventory. The Supply Agreement is
subject to certain termination provisions. Barnes &#038; Noble.com purchased
$108,269, $119,290 and $110,462 of merchandise from the Company during fiscal
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively, and Barnes &#038; Noble.com expects to source
purchases through the Company in the future.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has entered into agreements whereby Barnes &#038; Noble.com
receives various services from the Company, including, among others, services
for payroll processing, benefits administration, insurance (property, casualty,
medical, dental, life, etc.), tax, traffic, fulfillment and telecommunications.
In accordance with the terms of such agreements, the Company has received, and
expects to continue to receive, fees in an amount equal to the direct costs
plus incremental expenses associated with providing such services. The Company
received $3,453, $5,465 and $1,699 for such services during fiscal 2002, 2001
and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate receivable (which is historically settled within 60&nbsp;days)
from Barnes &#038; Noble.com in connection with the agreements described above was
$55,174 and $47,204 as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company and Barnes &#038; Noble.com commenced a marketing program in
November 2000, whereby a customer purchases a &#147;Readers&#146; Advantage&#153; card&#148; for an
annual membership fee of $25.00 which is non-refundable after the first 30&nbsp;days
of the membership term. With this card, customers can receive discounts of 10
percent on all Company purchases and 5&nbsp;percent on all Barnes &#038; Noble.com
purchases. The Company and Barnes &#038; Noble.com have agreed to share the
expenses, net of revenue from the sale of the cards, related to this program in
proportion to the discounts customers receive on purchases with each company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2002, the Company through its wholly owned subsidiary, Marketing
Services (Minnesota) Corp., entered into an agreement with Barnes &#038; Noble.com
for marketing services, which includes the issuance of gift cards. Under this
agreement, the Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com $5,273 during fiscal 2002, which
represents reimbursement for gift cards purchased in a Barnes &#038; Noble store and
redeemed on the Barnes &#038; Noble.com Web site.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-55</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble.com, through its fulfillment centers, ships various
customer orders for the Company to its retail stores as well as to the
Company&#146;s customers&#146; homes. Barnes &#038; Noble.com charges the Company the costs
associated with such shipments plus any incremental overhead incurred by Barnes
&#038; Noble.com to process these orders. The Company paid Barnes &#038; Noble.com
$1,746, $1,030 and $222 for shipping and handling during fiscal 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively. In addition, during fiscal 2001, the Company and Barnes &#038;
Noble.com reached an agreement whereby the Company pays a commission on all
items ordered by customers at the Company&#146;s stores and shipped directly to
customers&#146; homes by Barnes &#038; Noble.com. Commissions paid for these sales were
$1,547 and $359 during fiscal 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company paid B&#038;N College certain operating costs B&#038;N College incurred
on the Company&#146;s behalf. These charges are included in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations and approximated $219, $188 and $264 for
fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. B&#038;N College purchased inventory, at
cost plus an incremental fee, of $44,944, $41,452 and $17,198 from the Company
during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. The Company charged B&#038;N
College $2,064, $1,517 and $1,331 for fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively, for capital expenditures, business insurance and other operating
costs incurred on its behalf.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses a jet aircraft owned by B&#038;N College and pays for the
costs and expenses of operating the aircraft based upon the Company&#146;s usage.
Such costs which include fuel, insurance, personnel and other costs
approximated $1,872, $2,228 and $2,401 during fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively, and are included in the accompanying consolidated statements of
operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Company acquired Babbage&#146;s Etc., one of the nation&#146;s
largest video-game and entertainment-software specialty retailers, a company
majority owned by Leonard Riggio, for $208,670. An independent Special
Committee of the Board of Directors negotiated and approved the acquisition on
behalf of the Company. The Company made an additional payment of $9,665 in
fiscal 2002 due to certain financial performance targets having been met during
fiscal 2001. In fiscal 2000, the Company acquired Funco, Inc. Through a
corporate restructuring, Babbage&#146;s Etc. became a wholly owned subsidiary of
Funco, Inc. and the name of Funco, Inc. was changed to GameStop, Inc. In fiscal
2002, the Company completed an initial public offering of its GameStop
subsidiary. The Company retained an approximate 63&nbsp;percent interest in
GameStop.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop operates departments within some of the Company&#146;s bookstores.
GameStop pays a license fee to the Company in an amount equal to 7&nbsp;percent of
the gross sales of such departments. The Company charged GameStop a license fee
of $1,103 in fiscal 2002.
GameStop participates in the Company&#146;s worker&#146;s compensation, property and
general liability insurance programs. The costs incurred by the Company under
these programs are allocated to GameStop based upon GameStop&#146;s total payroll
expense, property and equipment, and insurance claim history. During fiscal
2002, these charges amounted to $1,726.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, Barnes &#038; Noble.com and GameStop entered into an agreement
whereby Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s Web site refers customers to the GameStop Web site
for purchases of video-game hardware, software and accessories and
PC-entertainment software. GameStop pays Barnes &#038; Noble.com a referral fee
based on its net sales revenue from certain eligible purchases made by
customers as a result of the redirection from the Barnes &#038; Noble.com Web site.
Either party may terminate the agreement on 60&nbsp;days&#146; notice. Commissions were
$14 and $89 for fiscal years 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is provided with national freight distribution, including
trucking, services by the LTA Group, Inc. (LTA), a company in which a brother
of Leonard Riggio owns a 20&nbsp;percent interest.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-56</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Company paid LTA $18,509,
$17,746 and $16,661 for such services during fiscal years 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively. The Company believes the cost of freight delivered to the stores
compares favorably to the prices charged by publishers and other third-party
freight distributors.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since 1993, the Company has used AEC One Stop Group, Inc. (AEC)&nbsp;as its
primary music and DVD/video supplier and to provide a music and video database.
AEC is one of the largest wholesale distributors of music and DVD/videos in
the United States. In 1999, AEC&#146;s parent corporation was acquired by an
investor group in which Leonard Riggio was a minority investor. The Company
paid AEC $246,409, $169,879 and $160,788 for merchandise purchased during
fiscal 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. In addition, the Company paid AEC
$7,736, $2,554 and $527 for database equipment and services during fiscal 2002,
2001 and 2000, respectively. Amounts payable to AEC for merchandise purchased
were $21,967 and $51,121 as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>21.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selected Quarterly Financial Information (Unaudited)</B>
</FONT>

fiscal years is as follows:

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-57</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>




<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT CERTIFIED PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Board of Directors<BR>
Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Barnes &#038;
Noble, Inc. and subsidiaries as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002 and
the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in shareholders&#146;
equity and cash flows for each of the three fiscal years in the period ended
February&nbsp;1, 2003. These financial statements are the responsibility of the
Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these
financial statements based on our audits.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally
accepted in the United States of America. Those standards require that we plan
and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the
financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes
examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting
principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as
evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our
audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above
present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Barnes &#038;
Noble, Inc. and its subsidiaries as of February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002
and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three
fiscal years in the period ended February&nbsp;1, 2003, in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements, effective
February&nbsp;3, 2002, the Company adopted Statement of Financial Standards No.&nbsp;142,
<I>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets.</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">New York, New York<BR>
March&nbsp;14, 2003
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">/s/BDO Seidman, LLP<BR>
<HR align="left" size="1" width="15%" noshade>BDO Seidman, LLP</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-58</FONT>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;23.1</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT CERTIFIED PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc.<BR>
New York, New York</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We hereby consent to the incorporation by reference of our report dated March
14, 2003 relating to the consolidated financial statements of Barnes &#038; Noble,
Inc. and subsidiaries, incorporated by reference into the Company&#146;s Annual
Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended February&nbsp;1, 2003, into the prospectuses
constituting a part of the following registration statements: No.&nbsp;33-84826 on
Form&nbsp;S-3, No.&nbsp;33-89258 on Form&nbsp;S-3, No.&nbsp;33-270333 on Form&nbsp;S-8, No.&nbsp;33-89260 on
Form&nbsp;S-8, and No.&nbsp;33-97410 on Form&nbsp;S-3.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We also consent to the references to us under the caption &#147;Experts&#148; in the
Prospectuses.

<TYPE>EX-23.2
<SEQUENCE>7
<FILENAME>y85716exv23w2.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-23.2: REPORT OF BDO SEIDMAN, LLP
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>EX-23.2: REPORT OF BDO SEIDMAN, LLP</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;23.2</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">REPORT OF INDEPENDENT CERTIFIED PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Board of Directors<BR>
Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The audits referred to in our report dated March&nbsp;14, 2003 relating to the
consolidated financial statements of Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. and subsidiaries
which is incorporated in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form&nbsp;10-K by reference to the annual
report to stockholders for the year ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 included the audit
of the financial statement schedules listed in the accompanying index. These
financial statement schedules are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s
management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial
statement schedules based upon our audits.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In our opinion such financial statement schedules present fairly, in all
material respects, the information set forth therein.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">BDO Seidman, LLP
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">New York, New York
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">April&nbsp;23, 2003
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">41</FONT>
</BODY>

&#147;Company&#148;) on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 as filed with
